blocks.string:
**Ladakh as Union Territory**
▪️ Ladakh became UT on ^^October 31, 2019^^
▪️ Ladakh is a ^^UT without legislature^^ i.e directly governed by Central Govt. via Lieutenant Governor (LG)
▪️ ^^Both Leh and Kargil^^ are joint capitals of UT Ladakh.


**Lieutenant Governors of UT Ladakh**
▪️ First Lt. governor was  ^^Radha Krishna Mathur^^ (Oct 2019 to Feb 2023)
▪️ Second Lt. governor was  ^^Brig. (Dr.) B.D. Mishra^^ (Feb 2023 to July 2025)
▪️ Third and Current Lt. governor is  ^^Kavinder Gupta^^ (From July 2025 ...)

**LAHDC**
▪️ LAHDC = Ladakh Autonomous Hill Development Council
▪️ Hill Council idea was ^^first implemented in Leh (1995)^^ on the pattern of Darjeeling Hill Development Council.
▪️ LAHDC Kargil was established in July 2003.
▪️ Created under the Ladakh Autonomous Hill Development Council Act, 1995

**LAHDC Structure:**
▪️ Total Councilors: 30
▪️ 26 elected from constituencies
▪️ 4 nominated (from principal minority & women folk) by the LG.

▪️ The council is led by a Chief Executive Councillor, who leads an executive committee of five members

**Oath be CEC**
▪️ The ^^Principal District and Sessions Judge^^ of district, a designated authority, administers the oath to the newly elected or nominated Chief Executive Councillor (CEC)
▪️ The current one is the 5th LAHDC term, since 2003.

**Ranks**
▪️ Chief Executive Councilor (CEC): Holds ^^Cabinet Minister rank^^ & powers.
▪️ Executive Councilors: Hold ^^Deputy Minister rank^^ & status.
▪️ Deputy Commissioner (DC): Also serves as Chief Executive Officer (CEO), LAHDC Kargil.


**Current Office Holders at KARGIL**
🔹 First CEC of LAHDC Kargil: ^^Qamar Ali Akhoon^^
🔹 Current CEC LAHDC Kargil: ^^Dr MOHD JAFFER AKHOON^^
🔹 Current DC Kargil: ^^Rakesh Kumar IAS^^
🔹 Current Chairman of DSSRB Kargil: (= DC Kargil) ^^Rakesh Kumar IAS^^

**Current Office Holders at LEH**
🔹 First CEC of LAHDC Leh: ^^Rigzin Spalbar^^
🔹 Current CEC LAHDC Leh: ^^Advocate Tashi Gyalson^^
🔹 Current DC Leh: ^^Shri Romil Singh Donk, IAS^^
🔹 Current Chairman of DSSRB Leh: (= DC Leh) ^^Shri Romil Singh Donk, IAS^^

**About Kargil War**
▪️ Fought in 1999 between India & Pakistan.
▪️ Cause: Pakistani infiltrators occupied Indian positions along the Line of Control (LoC).
▪️  **Operation Vijay**: India’s military mission to expel intruders.
▪️ **Kargil Vijay Diwas**: Celebrated on July 26, 1999 (victory day).
▪️ **Operation Safed Sagar**: Conducted by Indian Air Force → supported ground troops with precision airstrikes.

**About Kargil:**
▪️ Kargil became a separate district in the Ladakh region during the year 1979 when it was bifurcated from the earstwhile Leh ditrict.
▪️ Ladakh Autonomous Hill Development Council Kargil was commissioned in July 2003 in the district.
▪️ Islam came to Kargil in 15th century. Mir Shams-ud-Din Iraqi, a scholar of Shia school of central Asia visited Baltistan and Kargil with his missionaries to preach Islam.
▪️ Kargil is called the ^^land of Agas^^ in the present day world.
▪️ The book “Kargil Blunder” was written by Parvez Dewan. 

Source: [kargil.nic.in](https://kargil.nic.in/history/)

children.string:
**Hemis National Park**
▪️ Only National Park in Ladakh
▪️ Only National Park in India north of the Greater Himalayas
▪️ Indias highest altitude National Park
▪️ Bounded by:
  • North: Indus River
  • South: Zanskar Range
▪️ ^^Famous for Snow Leopards, which is state animal of Ladakh^^
▪️ Only refuge in India for Shapu (Ladakhi Urial)

**Changthang Wildlife Sanctuary**
▪️ Located in the Changthang Plateau
▪️ Includes Tso Moriri Lake (4595 m) – one of the highest lakes on Earth
▪️ Korzok Monastery located on NW bank of Tso Moriri
▪️ Major Fauna: Snow Leopard, Kiang (Tibetan Wild Ass – LC), Argali (Great Tibetan Sheep – NT)

**Karakoram (Nubra Shyok) Wildlife Sanctuary**
▪️ High-altitude WLS located in the eastern Karakoram range
▪️ Known for migratory population of Chiru / Tibetan Antelope (NT)

**Ramsar Sites of UT of Ladakh (2)**
1. Tso Kar 
2. Tso Moriri: 
▪️ Only breeding ground outside China for ^^Black-Necked Crane^^, which is state animal of Ladakh.

**State Animal**
▪️ ^^Snow leopard^^ is the state animal of Ladakh. 
▪️ The Hemis national park, the only national park in ladakh, is known for snow leopard.
▪️ International Day of the Snow Leopard is 23rd October
**Project Snow Leopard**
▪️ Project Snow Leopard is a 2009 initiative by the Indian government to conserve snow leopards and their high-altitude Himalayan habitats through a participatory, landscape-based approach. 
▪️ The project is active in five states: Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Sikkim, and Arunachal Pradesh. 
▪️ Its main goals include balancing human needs with conservation, using sound scientific knowledge for planning, building capacity among local communities and staff, and implementing community-based conservation programs

**State Bird**
▪️ State bird of Ladakh is ^^Black necked crane^^.
▪️ The Tso Moriri Ramsar site, located in Ladakh, is recognized as the only breeding ground in India for this globally threatened species. 
▪️ It is also a significant breeding site for other species, including the bar-headed goose

**State Tree**
▪️ The State Tree of the Ladakh is the ^^Juniper^^, known locally as Shukpa.

blocks.string:
**Protected Areas in Ladakh:**
▪️ Ladakh has ^^only one national park^^ i.e Hemis National Park.
▪️ Ladakh has ^^two Wildlife Sanctuaries^^: Changthang Wildlife Sanctuary and Karakoram (Nubra Shyok) Wildlife Sanctuary
▪️ Ladakh has ^^two ramsar sites^^: Tso Kar  and Tso Moriri

children.string:
**Suru River**
▪️ Suru river originates from a glacier near Shinkula pass, which comes on the way NH-301 that connects Kargil-Zanskar
▪️ From there it flows north direction
▪️ It merges with Shingo (Drass) river before merging Indus in the Gilgit-Baltistan region.
▪️ It is a left bank minor tributary of Indus

**Zanskar River**
▪️ Zanskar river originates from a glacier near Shinkula pass, which comes on the way NH-301 that connects Kargil-Zanskar
▪️ From there it flows south direction
▪️ It is a left bank minor tributary of Indus

**Nubra River**
▪️ Originates from Siachen glacier, which is in Karakoram range.
▪️ It passes through Nubra valley.
▪️ It is a tributary of the Shyok River, which is itself a part of the Indus River system.  
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2F8269ZIJkkK.png?alt=media&token=bc3f18d6-06e7-4880-8292-78f8cbf1c99b)


**Siachen Glacier**
▪️ The Siachen Glacier is located in the Eastern Karakoram range.
▪️ It is the 2nd-Longest glacier in the World outside the polar region.
▪️ It is the source for the 50m long Nubra River, a tributary of the Shyok, which is part of the Indus River system.
▪️ The Siachen Glacier is part of Ladakh which has now been converted into a Union Territory.
▪️ The Siachen Glacier is the world's highest battlefield.​

blocks.string:

▪️ The Leh city is on the bank of Indus river.
▪️ The Kargil city is on the bank of Suru river.

**Official Languages of UT Ladakh**
▪️ Ladakh has 5 official languages.
▪️ These are: Purgi, Bhoti, Urdu, Hindi, and English.
▪️ English will continue to be used for most official purposes, while the other languages are now also officially recognized

**Project Name: Nimoo Bazgo (on Indus River)**
Capacity (MW): 45
Status: Operational (2011)
Key Notes: Largest in Ladakh; developed by NHPC; supplies power to Leh region; compliant with Indus Waters Treaty.


**Project Name: Chutak (on Suru River)**
Capacity (MW): 44
Status: Operational (2013)
Key Notes: Major NHPC project; dedicated to Kargil supply; 4x11 MW units; connected to Northern Grid.

**About Pangong Lake**
▪️ Pangong Lake is a high-altitude, endorheic salt lake in the Himalayas.
▪️ It is  one of the highest brackish water lakes in the world
▪️ It is spread both in India and China
▪️ The lake is almost 5km wide and 134km long, with **one-third** of it lying in India and the other two-thirds in China.
▪️ It is not a ramsar site. 
▪️ The most gripping fact about this lake is that it changes color appearing blue, grey-green, and red at varied points in time. 
▪️ During winter, the lake freezes completely despite being saline water.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FkkyUTufqdG.png?alt=media&token=e4452dc4-6631-42a7-8bfe-0075705120b4)

**Shanti stupa**
▪️ The Shanti stupa is located in Leh district of Ladakh.
▪️ It was built in 1991 by Japanese Buddhist Bhikshu and Gyomyo Nakamura.
▪️ The stupa consists of a photograph of the Dalai Lama with the relics of the Buddha at the base.
▪️ The structure of the stupa is a "two-level structure".
The purpose of the construction of Stupa is to promote world peace and prosperity.
▪️ It symbolizes the relationship between the people of Japan and Ladakh.
▪️ A similar structure is built in New Delhi in Kale Khan 
▪️ It was inaugurated by current 14th Dalai Lama

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2Fz4VFLtGrTQ.png?alt=media&token=47b5b044-1309-466c-836e-4c4ecaa896fc)

**Passes in Ladakh**

▪️ The ^^highest pass in Ladakh is Mig La Pass^^, which is also the world's highest motorable road at 19,400 feet. 
▪️ The Border Roads Organisation (BRO) constructed this road, which was completed in October 2025, surpassing the previous record held by Umling La Pass. 

**Top three passes of Ladakh:**
1. Mig La pass (19400 ft)
2. Umling La pass (19,024 ft)
3. Khardung la pass (18,379 ft)

▪️ Khardung la is the gateway to Shyok and Nubra valleys and it leads to endless scenic vistas.

▪️ Mig La is situated in the Himalayan mountain range. 
▪️ Umling La is part of the Ladakh mountain ranges. 
▪️ Khardung La Pass is located in the Ladakh Range, a sub-range of the Himalayas. 
▪️ The Zojila Pass ( 11500 ft) is in the Zanskar Range of the Himalayas.

**Other Important Facts:**

▪️ Lamayuru: it is also known as the Moonland of Ladakh.
▪️ Magnetic hill that is believed to defy gravity is located at a distance of 30km(s) from Leh on the Leh-Kargil Highway

**Nubra Vallye**
▪️ NubraValley is known as the orchard of Ladakh
▪️ Khardungla pass connects Nubra valley with Leh.
▪️ The 108ft tall Statue of Maitreya Buddha is in Nubra valley.
▪️ Double-humped camels (Bactrian camels) are mainly found in the Nubra Valley region of Ladakh, particularly in the Hunder village.

**Schemes Mentioned in UT Ladakh Govt Website:**
[link here](https://ladakh.gov.in/provider/central-government/)

**Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana – Gramin (PMAY-G)**
▪️ Provide pucca houses with basic amenities to rural poor/homeless and those living in kutcha houses.  

**Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana (Urban)**  
▪️ Ensure affordable housing for urban poor, slum dwellers, and EWS/LIG categories.  

**Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY)**  
▪️ Provide all-weather road connectivity to unconnected rural habitations (250+ population in plains, 100+ in hilly areas).  

**Pradhan Mantri Kaushal Vikas Yojana (PMKVY)**  
▪️ Skill training of youth for employment/entrepreneurship through short-term courses and recognition of prior learning.  

**Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi (PM-KISAN)**  
▪️ Provide ₹6,000 per year income support to small & marginal farmer families (in 3 equal installments).  

**Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA)**  
▪️ Provide 100 days of guaranteed wage employment per year to rural households for unskilled manual work.

children.string:
**Attorney General of India**
▪️ Constitutional post under **Article 76**.
▪️ Appoint by the president
▪️ He is the "**first law officer**" of India.

**Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG)**
▪️ Constitutional post under **Article 148**.
▪️ Appoint by the president
▪️ As per Dr Ambedkar, CAG is the **most important officer in the Indian Constitution**

**State Election Commission**
▪️ Constitutional body under **Article 243**.
▪️ It is a single member body, who is appoint by the Governor of the state
▪️ It conducts local elections i.e elections of Panchayats and Municipalities
---
((4VAEyKG-X))

**GST Council**
▪️ Constitutional body under Article 279A.
▪️ Article 279A was added by 101st amendment act, 2016
▪️ Its chairman is Union Finance Minister
▪️ It has 33 members i.e from Union (2), States (28) and UTs with legislature(3).

**Finance Commission**
▪️ Constitutional body under Article 280.
▪️ It is a five member body.
▪️ Members are appointed by the President.
▪️ It recommends distribution of taxes between center and the states.

**Public Service Commissions (PSCs)**
▪️ Union-PSCs and State-PSCs are constitutional bodies
▪️ Joint-PSC is a statutory body i.e establish by the Parliament through an Act
▪️ Their role is to recruit officers for various departments in union and state governments.
---
((4VAEyKG-X))

**Election Commission of India (ECI)** 
▪️ Constitutional body under Article 324.
▪️ It is a five member body.
▪️ Members are appointed by the President.
▪️ It conducts elections of president, vice-president, lok sabha, rajya sabha, state assemblies and state councils.
▪️ The first ECI was appointed on Jan 25 1950, and thus "Jan 25" is celebrated as "national voters day" in India.

**National Commission for SCs**
▪️ Constitutional body under Article 338.
▪️ It is a five member body, One Chairperson, one Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members.
▪️ At least one of the three other members being a woman.
▪️ Members are appointed by the President.
▪️ They serve a three-year term
▪️ It deals with the welfare and safeguard of SCs in India

**National Commission for STs**
▪️ Constitutional body under Article 338A.
▪️ The Article 338A was added via  89th amendment act 2003. 
▪️ It is a five member body, One Chairperson, one Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members.
▪️ At least one of the three other members being a woman.
▪️ Members are appointed by the President.
▪️ They serve a three-year term
▪️ It deals with the welfare and safeguard of STs in India

**National Commission for OBCs**
▪️ Constitutional body under Article 338B.
▪️ The Article 338B was added via  102nd amendment act 2018. 
▪️ It is a five member body, One Chairperson, one Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members.
▪️ At least one of the three other members being a woman.
▪️ Members are appointed by the President.
▪️ They serve a three-year term
▪️ It deals with the welfare and safeguard of OBCs in India

There bodies are there who members are appoint by the Governor of the state but remove by the President. 
These bodies are:
1. State Election Commission
2. State Public Service Commission
3. State Human Rights Commission

blocks.string: Constitutional Bodies

**History of Making of Constituent Assembly**
▪️ M.N. Roy,  in 1934 for the first time suggested for making a constitution assembly to draft a constitution for India. 
▪️ Then it was Jawaharlal Nehru, who in Lucknow session of INC 1936, first time officially demand for a Constituent Assembly to draft a constitution.
▪️ The Britishers for the first time agreed to form Constituent Assembly  in "August Offer 1940" with mainly Indians.
▪️ The Britishers for the first time agreed to form Constituent Assembly  in "Cripps Mission 1946" with majority Indians
▪️ But the Constituent Assembly was finally established in 1946 as per the recommendation of "Cabinet Mission Plan, 1946". As per which the "Constituent Assembly" had 389 members.

**Dec 09 1946:** 
▪️ The members of the Constituent Assembly met for the first time.
▪️ Total 299 members were there, as Muslim League boycotted the session.
▪️ Dr Sachiananda Sinha was appointed as temporary(provisional) president.

**Dec 11 1946:** 
▪️ Election for the president and vice-president of the constituent assembly was held.
▪️ **Dr Rajandra Prasad** was elected as the president.
▪️ There were two vice presidents of the constituent assembly. *H C Mukharjee** and **V.T. Krishnamachari** were elected as the vice-presidents. They were elected to assist Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who was the president of the constituent assembly.
▪️ B. N Rao was the constitutional advisor of the constituent assembly.

**Dec 13 1946:** 
▪️ Jawaharlal Nehru moved the "objective resolution" in the assembly.
▪️ "Objective resolution" was passed unanimously in the assembly on Jan 22 1947.
▪️ Later on the last working day of the constituent assembly i.e Jan 24 1950, this objective resolution was adopted as preamble.

**July 22 1947:** 
▪️  The national flag was adopted by the constituent assembly.

**Nov 26 1949:**
▪️ On this day the constituent assembly adopted the constitution, and this constitution later came info effect on Jan 26, 1950.
▪️ This date "Nov 26 1949" is mentioned in the preamble of the constitution.
▪️ This day i.e "Nov 26" is celebrated as the "constitution day" in India. 
▪️ "Dr B R Ambedkar" was known as the "father of Indian Constitution"

**Jan 24 1950:**
▪️ It was the last working day of the constituent assembly.
▪️ On this day the Constituent Assembly adopted three things i.e national anthem, national song and preamble.
▪️ The "objective resolution", with some modifications, adopted as the the preamble of the constitution.

**January 26, 1950 – When India became Republic**
▪️  On this day, the Constitution of India came into effect.
▪️  Dr. Rajendra Prasad, the President of the Constituent Assembly, took oath as the first President of India.
▪️ India thus became a Republic, and hence 26th January is celebrated as Republic Day every year.
▪️ The President of India is the Head of the State. A country where the Head of State is an elected representative is known as a Republic.
▪️ Between 15th August 1947 (Independence) and 26th January 1950, India’s Head of State was the Governor-General, and India functioned as a British Dominion.
▪️ From 26th January 1950, the President replaced the Governor-General as the elected Head of State, making India a Sovereign and Republic State.
---
▪️ Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the first president of India.
▪️ Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the only president of India having two terms (1950-55-60).

**Aug 15, 1947 When India Got Independence**
▪️ India got Independence.

▪️ Before "Aug 15, 1947", India was a British Colony, and the governor-general was appointed by British crown. 
▪️ Last governor-general of British India was Lord Mountbatten.
----
▪️ After "Aug 15, 1947" India became a "British Dominion"
▪️ Free India had two governor-generals.
▪️ First "governor-general" of free India was Lord Mountbatten
▪️ Second "governor-general" of free India was Rajagopalachari, who was also the only and first Indian governor general. 
-----
▪️ After "Jan 26, 19450" India became a "Sovereign and Republic" state, 
▪️ President replaced governor-general as the head of the state.
▪️ Dr Rajandra Prasad took oath as the first president of India.

**DRAFTING COMMITEE**
▪️ Drafting committee was the most important committee of the constituent assembly.
▪️ It has 7 members.
▪️ Dr B.R. Ambedkar was the chairman of the drafting committee.
▪️ Dr B.R. Ambedkar is also known as "father of the Indian constitution" or "architect of the indian constitution"

**1st Amendment Act, 1951**
▪️ Saved laws for acquisition of estates, etc.
▪️ Added Ninth Schedule to protect land reform laws from judicial review.
▪️ Empowered states to make special provisions for socially and economically backward classes.
▪️ Added three new grounds for restricting freedom of speech: public order, friendly relations with foreign states, incitement to offence. Made restrictions “reasonable” and justiciable.
▪️ State trading/nationalisation not invalid on grounds of violating right to trade.
▪️ Inserted Articles 31A and 31B.

**2nd Amendment Act, 1952**
▪️ Adjusted Lok Sabha representation: one member could represent more than 7,50,000 persons.

**7th Amendment Act, 1956**
▪️ Abolished classification of states (Part A, B, C, D); reorganized into 14 states and 6 union territories.
▪️ Extended High Court jurisdiction to union territories; allowed common High Court for multiple states.
▪️ Provided for additional and acting judges in High Courts.
Amended Second Schedule.
▪️ Modified lists on acquisition/requisition of property in Seventh Schedule.

**10th Amendment Act, 1961**
▪️ Incorporated Dadra and Nagar Haveli into Indian Union.
▪️ Enabled President to make regulations for peace, progress, and good governance of the territory.

**15th Amendment Act, 1963**
▪️ Allowed High Courts to issue writs outside territorial jurisdiction if cause of action arises within limits.
▪️ Raised retirement age of High Court judges from 60 to 62 years.
▪️ Amended Articles 297, 311, 316.
▪️ Allowed appointment of retired High Court judges as acting judges.
▪️ Provided compensatory allowance for transferred judges.
▪️ Enabled retired High Court judges to act as ad-hoc Supreme Court judges.

**24th Amendment Act, 1971**
▪️ Affirmed Parliament’s power to amend any part of Constitution, including Fundamental Rights.
▪️ Made it compulsory for President to assent to Constitutional Amendment Bills.
▪️ Amended Article 13 to exclude constitutional amendments from its scope under Article 368.

**25th Amendment Act, 1971**
▪️ Introduced Article 31C to give primacy to certain Directive Principles over Fundamental Rights.
▪️ Limited right to property.

**34th Amendment Act, 1975**
▪️ Added 20 more land reform acts of various states to the Ninth Schedule.

**38th Amendment Act, 1975**
▪️ Made President’s satisfaction in declaring emergency non-justiciable.
▪️ Made ordinances by President, Governors, and UT administrators non justiciable.
▪️ Allowed President to declare different types of national emergency simultaneously.
▪️ Amended Articles 123, 213, 239B, 352, 356, 359, 360.

**42nd Amendment Act, 1976 (Mini Constitution)**
▪️ Added Socialist, Secular, Integrity to the Preamble.
▪️ Added Fundamental Duties (Part IVA).
▪️ President bound by Council of Ministers’ advice (Article 74).
▪️ Added Part XIVA – Administrative and other tribunals.
▪️ Froze Lok Sabha/state assembly seats based on 1971 census till 2001.
▪️ Made constitutional amendments beyond judicial review.
▪️ Increased tenure of Lok Sabha and assemblies from 5 to 6 years.
▪️ Protected laws implementing Directive Principles from being void on grounds of violating certain FRs.
▪️ Added 3 new Directive Principles: equal justice & free legal aid, worker participation in management, protection of environment/forests/wildlife.
▪️ Allowed national emergency in part of India.
▪️ Extended President’s Rule from 6 months to 1 year at a time.
▪️ Shifted 5 subjects (education, forests, wildlife, weights & measures, administration of justice) from State to Concurrent List.
▪️ Provided for All-India Judicial Service.

**44th Amendment Act, 1978**
▪️ Restored some powers of Supreme Court and High Courts.
▪️ Replaced “internal disturbance” with “armed rebellion” for national emergency.
▪️ President to declare emergency only on written Cabinet advice.
▪️ Removed right to property from Fundamental Rights (made legal right).
▪️ Ensured Articles 20 and 21 cannot be suspended during emergency.

**51st Amendment Act, 1984**
▪️ Reserved seats for Scheduled Tribes in Lok Sabha from Meghalaya, Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland, Mizoram; and in assemblies of Meghalaya and Nagaland.

**52nd Amendment Act, 1985 (Anti-Defection Law)**
▪️ Disqualified MPs/MLAs on grounds of defection.
Added Tenth Schedule.

**61st Amendment Act, 1989**
▪️ Reduced voting age from 21 to 18 years for Lok Sabha and Assembly elections.

**65th Amendment Act, 1990**
▪️ Replaced Special Officer for SC/ST with National Commission for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

**69th Amendment Act, 1991**
▪️ Granted National Capital Territory status to Delhi with a 70-member assembly and 7-member Council of Ministers.

**73rd Amendment Act, 1992**
▪️ Gave constitutional status to Panchayati Raj Institutions (Part IX).
▪️ Added Eleventh Schedule (29 subjects).
▪️ Three-tier system; reservation for SC/ST and 1/3rd for women.

**74th Amendment Act, 1992**
▪️ Gave constitutional status to urban local bodies (Part IX-A).
▪️ Added Twelfth Schedule (18 functions of municipalities).

**76th Amendment Act, 1994**
▪️ Included Tamil Nadu’s 69% reservation law in Ninth Schedule to protect from judicial review (despite 50% cap).

**77th Amendment Act, 1995**
▪️ Provided reservation in promotions for SC/ST in government jobs.

**85th Amendment Act, 2001**
▪️ Provided consequential seniority in promotions for SC/ST employees.

**86th Amendment Act, 2002**
▪️ Made elementary education (6–14 years) a Fundamental Right (Article 21A).
▪️ Modified Article 45 (DPSP).
▪️ Added Fundamental Duty for parents to provide education to children aged 6–14 (Article 51A).

**91st Amendment Act, 2003**
▪️ Limited size of Council of Ministers (Centre & States).
▪️ Strengthened anti-defection law; barred defectors from public office.

**93rd Amendment Act, 2005**
▪️ Provided reservation for OBCs in private unaided educational institutions (except minority institutions).

**97th Amendment Act, 2012**
▪️ Gave constitutional status to co-operative societies.

**99th Amendment Act, 2014**
▪️ Replaced collegium system with National Judicial Appointments Commission (NJAC) for appointing judges.
▪️ Struck down by Supreme Court in 2015; collegium system restored.

**100th Amendment Act, 2015**
▪️ Gave effect to India-Bangladesh Land Boundary Agreement – exchange of enclaves.

**101st Amendment Act, 2016**
▪️ Introduced Goods and Services Tax (GST).

**102nd Amendment Act, 2018**
▪️ Gave constitutional status to National Commission for Backward Classes (NCBC).
▪️ President to specify backward classes for each state/UT.

**103rd Amendment Act, 2019**
▪️ Provided 10% reservation for Economically Weaker Sections (EWS) in education and government jobs (except minority institutions).

**104th Amendment Act, 2020**
▪️ Extended reservation for SCs and STs in the Lok Sabha (Article 330) and State Legislative Assemblies (Article 332) from 70 years to 80 years.
▪️ Removed reserved seats for the Anglo-Indian community in the Lok Sabha and State Assemblies (Article 334).
--
Article 330: SC ST reservation in lok sabha
Article 332: SC ST reservation in State Legislative Assemblies
Article 334: reserved seats for the Anglo-Indian community (now repealed)

children.string:
▪️ The term ‘preamble’ refers to the introduction or preface to the Constitution. 
▪️ It contains the summary or essence of the Constitution. 
▪️ The Preamble outlines the philosophy, values, and principles that the Indian Constitution is based on, providing a concise summary of its essence.
▪️ The American Constitution was the first to begin with a Preamble. 
▪️ The idea of Preamble in the Constitution was borrowed from USA constitution.
▪️NA Palkhivala called the Preamble as the ‘identity card of the Constitution

▪️The Preamble to the Indian Constitution is based on the Objectives Resolution. 
▪️ This resolution was drafted and introduced by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in the Constituent Assembly on December 13, 1946. 
▪️It was unanimously accepted by the Assembly on January 22, 1947.

▪️ Later, on the last working day of the Constituent Assembly — which was January 24, 1950 — the Objectives Resolution, with a few changes, was adopted as the Preamble to the Indian Constitution.

blocks.string: Introduction
TEXT OF THE PREAMBLE

**BORROWED FEATURES** 
▪️ The idea of preamble in the constitution was borrowed from USA constitution.
▪️ The idea of "JUSTICE" in the preamble was borrowed from USSR constitution ( or Russian revolution).
▪️ The idea of "Republic, LIBERTY, EQUALITY, FRATERNITY" in the preamble was borrowed from French constitution ( or French revolution).

children.string:
The Preamble reveals four ingredients or components:

**Source of authority of the Constitution: **
▪️ The Preamble states that the Constitution derives its authority from the people of India.

**Nature of Indian State: **
▪️ It declares India to be of a sovereign, socialist, secular democratic and republican polity.

**Objectives of the Constitution: **
▪️ It specifies justice, liberty, equality and fraternity as the objectives.

**Date of adoption of the Constitution:** 
▪️ The date November 26th 1949 is mentioned in the preamble, as on this date the Constituent Assembly adopted the constitution. 
▪️ This very date is celebrated as "**national constitution day**" in India. 
▪️ Though the constitution was **adopted** on "Nov 26 1949" but it **came into force** two months later i.e on "January 26th 1950", that is when India became a sovereign republic state.
▪️ The difference between these two dates is 61 days.

blocks.string: INGREDIENTS OF THE PREAMBLE

children.string:
Sovereign means that a country is free from external control and has full autonomy to govern itself without interference from any external authority.

**Timeline of India’s Sovereignty:**

**Before August 15, 1947:  **
India was a British colony and was under the direct control of the British Empire.

**From August 15, 1947, to January 26, 1950:**
India became a British Dominion after gaining independence.
During this period, India was self-governing but still recognized the British Crown as the nominal head of state.

**From January 26, 1950:**
It was on this date Indian constitution came into force and India officially becoming a sovereign, democratic, and republic state. The Constitution of India came into force, marking full independence and the establishment of India's identity as a sovereign nation.

India is described as a secular state in the Preamble to the Constitution of India, which ensures that
1. The state has no official religion.
2. All religions are treated equally by the state.
3. The government does not favor or discriminate against any religion.
The term "Secular" was added in the preamble by the 42nd Amendment 1976.

blocks.string: Meaning of Keywords

children.string:
The Indian Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949, while the Preamble was adopted later, on January 24, 1950, which was the last working day of the Constituent Assembly. 
This raised a controversy about whether the Preamble was actually a part of the Constitution.

**Supreme Court Verdicts on the Preamble:**
**Berubari Case (1960):**
▪️ Preamble is not a part of the Constitution.
▪️ Preamble can still be used as a guiding source for interpreting the Constitution.

**Kesavananda Bharati Case (1973):**
▪️ Preamble is indeed a part of the Constitution.
▪️ it can be amended like any other provision of the Constitution, as long as such amendments do not alter the basic structure of the Constitution.

**42nd Amendment amended Preamble**
▪️ In Kesavananda Bharati Case (1973), SC held that preamble can be amended.
▪️ Preamble was amended in 1976 via 42nd Amendment Act 1976.
▪️ Through this amendment three new keywords were added in the preamble which are "SOCIALIST, SECULAR and Integrity"
▪️ So far, the Preamble has been amended only once, in 1976.

blocks.string: PREAMBLE AS PART OF THE CONSTITUTION

▪️ Part-III (Article 12-35) of the constitution deals with Fundamental Rights.
▪️ They are called as fundamental rights because they are **guaranteed** rights. 
▪️ **Justiciable:** These rights are enforceable by the courts, meaning individuals can approach the judiciary if they feel their rights are being violated.
▪️ They apply universally to all citizens, irrespective of race, religion, caste, gender, or place of birth.
▪️ Five fundamental rights are only available to Indian citizens which are: Article 15, 16, 19, 29, 30.
▪️ They are not absolute and the state can put reasonable restrictions.

▪️ The original constitution (Jan 26, 1950) has seven fundamental rights.
🔹In 1978, the "Right to Property" was removed from Part III (Article 31) and moved to Part XII (Article 300A) by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978
▪️  Thus as of 2025, we have six fundamental rights. 

**The Six Fundamental Rights are:**
1. Right to Equality ( 14-18)
2. Right to Freedom ( 19-22)
3. Right Against Exploitation (23-24)
4. Right to Freedom of Religion ( 25-28)
5. Cultural and Educational Rights (29-30)
6. Right to Constitutional Remedies (32)

🔹Thus at present the "Right to Property" is a constitutional right under Part XII (Article 300A) by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978.

**Right to Equality (Articles 14–18)**

**Article 14 – Equality before Law**
▪️ All persons are equal before the law.
▪️ No one is above the law (including govt. officials).

**Article 15 – No Discrimination**
▪️ No discrimination by the State on the grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
▪️ However, special provisions allowed for women, children, SCs, STs, and OBCs.

**Article 16 – Equal Opportunity in Public Jobs**
▪️ Equal chance for all citizens in public employment.
▪️ Reservations allowed for backward classes, SCs, STs, and economically weaker sections (EWS).

**Article 17 – Abolition of Untouchability**
▪️ Practice of untouchability is prohibited in any form.
▪️ Punishable offence under law.

**Article 18 – Abolition of Titles**
▪️ No titles (like Raja, Maharaja, Rai Bahadur) can be given.
▪️ Exception → Military & Academic titles (e.g., Doctor, Major, Professor).

**Right to Freedom ( Article 19-22)**

**Article 19 – Six Fundamental Freedoms**
▪️ Every citizen has six freedoms:
1. Freedom of speech & expression
2. Freedom to assemble peacefully
3. Freedom to form associations/unions
4. Freedom to move freely throughout India
5. Freedom to reside in any part of India
6. Freedom to practice any profession or carry on any occupation, trade, or business
▪️ Restrictions possible in interest of public order, morality, security, sovereignty of India, etc.

**Article 20 – Protection in Criminal Cases**
▪️ No ex-post facto law – No punishment for an act that was not an offence under law when committed.
▪️ No double jeopardy – Cannot be punished twice for the same offence.
▪️ No self-incrimination – No person can be forced to be a witness against himself.

**Article 21 – Right to Life & Personal Liberty**
▪️ No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
▪️ Expanded by SC to include: right to privacy, clean environment, livelihood, shelter, health, speedy trial, etc.

**Article 21A – Right to Education**
▪️ Free & compulsory education for children aged 6–14 years.
▪️ Inserted by 86th Amendment Act, 2002.

**Article 22 – Protection against Arrest & Detention**
▪️ Provides rights to persons arrested.
▪️ Preventive detention allowed but with limits:
– Maximum 3 months, can be extended with approval of an advisory board.
– Parliament can prescribe longer periods.

**Right Against Exploitation (Articles 23–24)**

**Article 23 – Ban on Human Exploitation**
▪️ Prohibits traffic in human beings (slavery, bonded labor, begar/forced labor).
▪️ Both the State and private individuals are prohibited from exploiting others.
▪️ The State can impose compulsory service for public purposes (e.g., military service, social service), but without discrimination.

**Article 24 – Ban on Child Labour**
▪️ Prohibits employment of children below 14 years in:
– factories
– mines
– hazardous occupations
▪️ Aim: To protect the health, safety, and dignity of children.

**Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25–28)**

**Article 25 – Freedom of Religion for Individuals**
▪️ Every person has freedom of conscience.
▪️ Right to profess, practice, and propagate any religion.
▪️ Subject to: public order, morality, health, and other fundamental rights.

**Article 26 – Freedom for Religious Communities**
▪️ Religious groups/denominations can:
- Establish and maintain religious institutions.
- Manage their own religious affairs.
- Own and acquire property.
- Administer property according to law.

**Article 27 – No Religious Taxes**
▪️ No person can be forced to pay taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any religion.

**Article 28 – Religious Instruction in Educational Institutions**
▪️ No religious instruction can be given in institutions wholly funded by the State.
▪️ In institutions managed by the State but established under an endowment or trust, religious instruction is allowed.
▪️ Students cannot be forced to attend religious instruction or worship

**Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29–30)**

**Article 29 – Protection of Interests of Minorities**
▪️ Any section of citizens having a distinct language, script, or culture has the right to conserve it.
▪️ No citizen can be denied admission into any state-run or state-aided educational institution on grounds of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them.

**Article 30 – Right of Minorities to Establish and Administer Institutions**
▪️ All religious and linguistic minorities have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
▪️ State cannot discriminate in granting aid to minority educational institutions.
▪️ This ensures minorities can preserve their culture and identity through education.

**Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)**
▪️ Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
▪️ Dr. B. R. Ambedkar called it the "Heart and Soul" of the Constitution.
▪️ It makes Fundamental Rights enforceable and justiciable.
▪️ Both Supreme Court (Art. 32) and High Courts (Art. 226) can issue writs.
▪️ This right acts as a guarantee against violation of Fundamental Rights.

**Five Writs under Article 32**

**Habeas Corpus** 
▪️ “Produce the body” 
▪️ Issued to release a person unlawfully detained.

**Mandamus** 
▪️ Means “We Command”
▪️ Issued to direct a public authority to perform its duty.

**Prohibition** 
▪️ Issued by a higher court to a lower court to stop it from exceeding its jurisdiction.

**Certiorari** 
▪️ Issued by a higher court to transfer or quash the order of a lower court.

**Quo Warranto** 
▪️ Means  “By what authority” 
▪️ Issued to check the legality of a person holding a public office.

** Fundamental Duties (FDs)**
▪️ Fundamental duties were ^^added in 1976^^ via ^^42nd Amendment, 1976^^
▪️ ^^Part-IVA (Article 51A)^^ deals with fundamental duties.
▪️ ^^Part-IVA (Article 51A)^^ was added in the constitution by ^^42nd Amendment, 1976^^.
▪️ They were on the recommendation of ^^Swaran Singh Committee^^
▪️ Fundamental Duties were ^^borrowed from USSR/Russia constitution^^
▪️ There are ^^11 fundamental duties^^.
▪️ In 1976, only 10 fundamental duties were added.
▪️ In 2002, the ^^11th fundamental duty^^ i.e “to provide opportunities for education to children (6–14 years)”  was added  by the ^^86th Amendment Act 2002^^

Watch Video: {video:jeT6uNaZ6Ds:0}

**The 11 Fundamental Duties  are:**

1. To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals, the National Flag & National Anthem.
2. To cherish and follow the noble ideals of the freedom struggle.
3. To uphold and protect sovereignty, unity & integrity of India.
4. To defend the country and render national service when called upon.
5. To promote harmony & brotherhood transcending religion, language & region, and respect women.
6. To value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture.
7. To protect and improve the natural environment (forests, lakes, rivers, wildlife) and show compassion for living beings.
8. To develop scientific temper, humanism & spirit of inquiry and reform.
9. To safeguard public property & abjure violence.
10. To strive towards excellence in all spheres, so that the nation constantly rises to higher levels of achievement.

11. To provide opportunities for education to children (6–14 years) → ^^added by 86th Amendment, 2002^^

▪️ ^^Part-VIII (Article 239-241)^^ of the constitution deals with Union Territories (UTs).
▪️ Union Territories are directly administered by the union government.
▪️ The idea of UTs was established in 1956 by the ^^7th amendment act, 1956^^.
▪️ In 1956, the act created 6 UTs which were:
Delhi, Manipur, Tripura, Himachal Pradesh, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, and Laccadive, Minicoy, and Amindivi (now Lakshadweep) Islands
▪️ As of (Aug 2025) there are ^^8 UTs^^ in India which are:
Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Chandigarh, Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu, Delhi, Jammu & Kashmir, Ladakh, Lakshadweep, and Puducherry
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FNh9msjcE7t.png?alt=media&token=aff19aad-29a3-4d72-bae4-6a6ed09139d8)

**UTs with Legislative Assembly**
▪️ The parliament can create legislature for UTs under ^^Article 239A.^^ 
▪️  The Article 239A was added via ^^14th Amendment Act, 1962^^
▪️ The Parliament under Article 239A established ^^legislature for Puducherry in 1963^^. 
▪️ In 1962 Puducherry became the first UT to have its own legislature. 
---
▪️ As of August 2025, only two UTs have legislative assembly i.e Puducherry (Article 239A) and NCT of Delhi (Article 239A)
▪️ The UT of Jammu and Kashmir, has given legislative assembly
▪️ The UT Ladakh is demanding legislative assembly. 
▪️ As of August 2025, ^^three UTs have legislative assembly^^ i.e Puducherry, NCT of Delhi and Jammu & Kashmir.

**NCT of Delhi**
▪️ In 1956, through the ^^7th Amendment Act, 1956^^, Delhi was given the status of a Union Territory.
▪️ Later, through the ^^69th Amendment Act, 1991, Article 239AA^^ was added to the Constitution, giving Delhi a ^^special status^^.
▪️ From then, Delhi is officially called the National Capital Territory (NCT) of Delhi.
▪️ Article 239AA provides Delhi with its own Legislative Assembly and Council of Ministers, headed by a Chief Minister.
▪️ The Delhi Government has control over all subjects of the State List, except three:
1. Land
2. Police
3. Public Order
▪️ In NCT of Delhi these ^^three subjects (land, police, and public order) are directly controlled by the Union Government^^.

**High Courts for UTs**
▪️ Article 241 of the Constitution gives Parliament the power to establish a High Court for any Union Territory.
▪️ As of August 2025, ^^only the NCT of Delhi has its own separate High Court^^.
▪️ The High Court of Delhi was established on 31st October, 1966
▪️ The Union Territory of Jammu & Kashmir and the Union Territory of Ladakh share a common High Court, called the High Court of Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh.

**Introduction**
▪️ The legislature in India is called as "Parliament".
▪️ The Parliament consists of three parts (Article 79):
(1) Upper House ( = Rajya Sabha)
(2) Lower House ( = Lok Sabha)
(3) The president.
▪️ The president is part of the parliament. 
▪️ Indian legislature is having two houses i.e upper and lower house, thus indian legislature i.e parliament is called as "bicameral legislature". 
▪️ The parlaiment, as legislative body, makes law for India in the form of Acts. 
▪️ To make a bill into act, first it has to be passed by both the houses, and then it had to get assent of the president, then only a bill becomes an act.

**Lok Sabha**
▪️ The lok sabha is the lower house of the parliament
▪️ Its strength is 550 i.e maximum 550 members.
▪️ Out of total 550 members, 530 members representing the States and 20 representing the Union Territories.
▪️ The tenure of lok sabha members is 5 years.

**Lok Sabha Speaker**
▪️ The head of the lok sabha is called as speaker.
▪️ Speaker is elected by the members of the house, from among them selves.
▪️ The tenure of the speaker is same as the members i.e 5 years.

**Rajya Sabha**
▪️ The lok sabha is the upper house of the parliament
▪️ Its strength is 250 i.e maximum 550 members
▪️ Out of 250, 238 are indirectly elected, and 12 are nominated by the president. 
▪️ The tenure of rajya sabha members is 6 years. 

**Rajya Sabha Chairman**
▪️ The head of the rajye sabha is called as chairman.
▪️ The  Vice President of India, acts as the chairman of the rajya sabha.
▪️ The tenure of the rajya sabha chairman is thus same as the vice president i.e 5 years.

**President as Supreme Commander of Defence**

▪️ Article 52 of the Indian Constitution states that there shall be a President of India. As the Supreme Commander, the President is the head of the Indian Army, Navy, and Air Force.
▪️ The  President is the commander of the defence forces of India. 
President appoints: Chief of the Army, Chief of the Navy, Chief of the Air Force 
▪️ The Chief of the Army is a **General**, the Chief of the Navy is an **Admiral**, and the Chief of the Air Force is an **Air Chief Marshal**. 
▪️ These three positions are collectively known as the armed forces chiefs

**INTRODUCTION**
▪️ The Indus Valley Civilization was established around 3300 BC 
▪️ It flourished between 2600 BC and 1900 BC . 
▪️ It started declining around 1900 BC and disappeared around 1400 BC. 

▪️ The Indus Valley Civilization is a **Bronze Age Civilization**. 📌 
▪️The other contemporary civilizations were – Egypt, Mesopotamia, & China.

▪️ Harappa was the first site of the Indus Valley Civilization to be discovered. 📌 
▪️ Harappa is located in present-day Punjab, Pakistan, 
▪️ Due to this, the Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Harappan Civilization.
▪️ It was discovered in 1921 by Dayaram Sahni. At that time, Sir John Marshall was the Director of the Archaeological Survey of India.
▪️ The excavations were carried out under the guidance of Sir John Marshall, the then Director of the Archaeological Survey of India.

▪️ Mohenjodaro was the largest site of the Harappan Civilization.  📌

**About Dholavira site:**
▪️ Dholavira is present in Gujarat, India.
▪️ It is the only World Heritage Site (WHS) from the Harappan civilization. 📌 
▪️ It is on the Khadir Beyt (island) in the Rann of Kutch in Gujarat where the famous Luni river flows. 

**Its Unique Feature**
▪️ In other sites, the city is divided into two parts, and each is surrounded by brick walls. However, in Dholavira, the city is divided into **three parts**, each surrounded by stone walls.
▪️ In other places, pictographic script was mainly found on seals, but in Dholavira, pictographic script was found written on **stones** and perhaps on wood.
▪️ It also has **water reservoirs** 📌

**About Lothal site**
▪️ Lothal site is present on the bank of river Bogava, which is a tributary of river Sabarmati in Gujurat. 

**Important discoveries at Lothal**
▪️ Warehouse: to store grains
▪️ Fire Alter
▪️ Double burial
▪️ Dockyard
▪️ Precious stones: site of making stone objects

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F30dtEkrQJr.png?alt=media&token=da4d933f-2f02-45db-a874-2360e3743754)

blocks.string: Economy

children.string:
▪️ The people of the Harappan civilization practiced agriculture. 
▪️ Evidence from Kalibangan in Rajasthan, where terracotta plough toys were found, suggests the use of bulls or cattle for ploughing. 
▪️ They also employed some form of irrigation. Water from nearby wells were used for irrigation.
▪️ The major crops grown were wheat, rice, barley, pulses, peas, and mustard. 
▪️ Cotton cultivation in Mehrgarh dates back to 7000 years ago, during Neolithic times.

▪️ Storehouses were present in major cities such as Harappa, Mohenjodaro, and Lothal. 
▪️ Common domesticated animals included cattle, bulls, goats, and sheep.
▪️ Bull being the most frequently depicted animal on seals.

blocks.string: Agriculture

children.string:
**Religion of Harappan People:**
▪️ The people of the Harappan civilization believed in some form of religion
▪️ But there is no evidence of temple-like structures. 
▪️ Evidence of **fire altars** from Kalibangan and Lothal suggests they practiced some rituals. 
▪️ The **Great Bath** from Mohenjodaro indicates that ritual bathing might have been practiced. 
▪️ **Pot burials** found in Surkotada suggest they buried their dead in this manner. Evidence also suggests that they worshipped plants and animals.
▪️ Evidences shows that they practised tree and animal worship,
▪️ They also believed in Ghosts.

**Burial Practises of Harappan People:**
▪️ **Double burial** was found at Lothal. Burial of a male & female person in a single grave is found here.
▪️ A **graveyard** was found in Harappa. Graveyard had 57 burials in total.
▪️ **Pot Burial:** At Surkotada, in Gujurat, four pot burials were found. Pot burials contained bone ashes.

blocks.string: Religion

children.string: Around 3900 years ago, many people stopped living in the cities of the Harappan civilization.
**River dried up:** One reason might be that the rivers dried up. Without rivers, it became difficult to get water for drinking and farming.

**Deforestation:** Another reason could be deforestation. People needed wood to bake bricks and to melt copper ores. They cut down many trees for this. Also, large herds of cattle, sheep, and goats ate the plants, making it hard for the trees to grow back.

**Flood:** In some places, there were floods. Too much water from the rivers could have damaged houses and fields. However, flooding or rivers drying up can't explain why all the cities were abandoned, since these issues would only affect certain areas.
**Over grazing:** Large herds of cattle, sheep, and goats may have eaten too much grass and plants. This would have left the land bare and unable to support farming or other activities.

**Aryan invasion:** Some scholars suggest that new groups of people, like the Aryans, moved into the area. This may have caused conflicts and changes in how the cities were controlled. As a result, people might have left the big cities and moved to smaller settlements in the east and south.

children.string:
**Birth of Buddha**
▪️ Buddha was born in around 563 BCE in Lumbini, Kapilavastu, (present day Nepal).
▪️ His real name was Siddharta Gautama
▪️ He belong to Kshatriya caste. 
▪️ His father name was Suddhodana, king of Sakya clan.
▪️ His mother name was Mahamaya, who died shortly after Buddha's birth.
▪️ Buddha was raised by Prajapati Gautami (Mahamaya’s sister and Suddhodana’s second wife).
▪️ At the age of 16, Buddha married Yashodhara. With Yashodhara, he had a son named Rahula.

**Buddha's Search for Truth**
▪️ At the age of 29, Siddhartha Gautama left his palace in search of truth.
▪️ This event is called the Great Renunciation or Mahabhinishkramana.
▪️ The horse on which he left was named Kanthaka.
▪️ He wandered for 6 years practicing austerities and meditation.
▪️ Buddha attained enlightenment at the age of 35 in Bodh Gaya.

**Buddha became Enlightened**
▪️ Buddha attained enlightenment at the age of 35.
▪️ Under the Bodhi (Peepal) tree, near the Neranjana River, in Bodh Gaya (present-day Bihar, India).
▪️ This event is called Nirvana, marking the attainment of supreme knowledge and freedom from the cycle of birth and death.

**Buddha Giving Sermons**
▪️ After attaining enlightenment, Buddha started giving sermons.
▪️ Buddha gave his first sermon at Sarnath, Uttar Pradesh.
▪️ This event is called Dhammacakkappavattana (Turning of the Wheel of Dharma).
▪️ The sermon introduced the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path, which are the core principles of Buddhism.

**Death of Buddha**
▪️ Buddha passed away at the age of 80 in Kushinagar, Uttar Pradesh, around 483 BCE. 
▪️ His death is referred to as Mahaparinirvana, marking his final release from the cycle of birth and rebirth.
▪️ Immediately After his death 1st buddhist council was held at Rajgir patronaged by king Ajatashatru of Haryanka dynasty.

blocks.string: About Buddha

children.string:
**First Buddhist Council**
▪️ Held in around 483 BC, just after the death of Buddha.
▪️ Patronage by Ajatashatru  king of Haryanka dynasty.
▪️ Presided by Mahakashyapa.
**Outcome:**
▪️ Compilation of Vinaya Pitaka and Sutta Pitaka.
▪️ Vinaya pitaka deals with the "monastic code of conduct".
▪️ Sutta pitaka deals with "teachings of Buddha"
((lArU0ei39))

**Second Buddhist Council**  
▪️ Held in around 383 BC (100 years after Buddha’s death) at Vaishali.
▪️ Patronaged by Kalashoka, king of Shishunaga dynasty.
▪️ Presided by Sabakami.

**Third Buddhist Council**
▪️ Held in around 250 BC at Pataliputra.
▪️ Patronage by emperor Ashoka (Maurya dynasty).
▪️ Presided by Moggaliputta Tissa.
**Outcome**
▪️ Compilation of Abhidhamma Pitaka.
▪️ Abhidhamma Pitaka deals with "buddhist philosophy"
((lArU0ei39))

**Fourth Buddhist Council**
▪️ Held in around 72 AD at Kundalvana (Kashmir).
▪️ Patronage by king Kanishka (Kushan dynasty).
▪️ Presided by Vasumitra and Asvaghosa (co-presidents).
▪️ Here buddhism divided into Mahayana and Hinayana, when the Mahayana buddhism started commentary on Buddhist texts in Sanskrit.

blocks.string: Buddhist Universities

children.string:
▪️ The religious books of Buddhism are called as Pitakas.
▪️ The Pitakas are written in the Pali language.
▪️ Pitaka means "basket," referring to the collection of Buddha's teachings.

**Types of Pitakas:**
**1. Sutta Pitaka:** Contains the teachings and discourses of Buddha.
**2. Vinaya Pitaka:** Details the monastic code of conduct for monks and nuns.
**3. Abhidhamma Pitaka:** Focuses on Buddhist philosophy and psychology.

**Compilation:**
▪️ Vinaya and Sutta Pitaka were compiled during the First Buddhist Council.
▪️ Abhidhamma Pitaka was compiled during the Third Buddhist Council.

blocks.string: Buddhist Religious Books

**Founder - Chandragupta Maurya (321 - 297 BC)**
▪️ Maurya empire was founded by **Chandragupta Maurya** in around 321 BC.
▪️ Chandragupta Maurya established "Maurya empire" by overthrowing Nanda dynasty.
▪️ He defeated the Dhanananda, the last ruler of Nanda dynasty.
▪️ Chandragupta Maurya was helped by **Chanakya (= Kautilya)**, who was an intelligent and politically astute Brahmin. 
▪️ **Patliputra** (present day Patna) was the capital of Maurya empire. 
▪️ Chanakya had written as book named **Arthashatra**, in Sanskrit, in which he mentioned about the different aspected of the Maurya empire. 

**Chandragupta & Jainism**
▪️ According to Jain tradition, Chandragupta Maurya adopted Jainism, abdicated his throne, and traveled to Karnataka (south India), where he died by practicing **Sallekhana** (also called **Santhara**), a ritualistic slow starvation to death. 
▪️ He was influenced by the Jain saint Bhadrabahu and spent his final years as an ascetic.

**Bindusara (297 - 273 BC )**
▪️ He was son of Chandragupta.
▪️ He is also called **Amitraghata** (Slayer of foes) or **Amitrochates** in Greek sources.
▪️ Deimachus was a Greek ambassador at his court.
▪️ He had appointed his son, Ashoka as the governor of Ujjain.
▪️ Bindusara is believed to have extended the Mauryan Empire to Mysore as well.
▪️ He was a follower of the **Ajivika sect** (an ancient heterodox tradition, like Buddhism and Jainism).

**Ashoka ( 273 - 232 BC)**
▪️ He was son of Bindusara.
▪️ He was the greatest ruler of Maurya empire.
▪️ His capital was Patliputra (present day Patna)
▪️ In 261 BC, he founght the Kaling war, and in which thousands of  people dies, and after this war Ashoke converted to buddhism. 
▪️ After this, he stoped fighting wars, and started spreading the message of buddhism all around.


▪️ At its zenith, Ashoka’s empire stretched from Afghanistan in the west to Bangladesh in the east. It covered almost the whole Indian subcontinent except present Kerala and Tamil Nadu, and modern-day Sri Lanka.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FysWQaPH4Em.png?alt=media&token=bf4dddbf-230c-4a07-9bcd-a5ded0223c7a)

**Ashoka & Kalinga war**
▪️The Kalinga war was fought in the year 261 BC. 
▪️ The Kalinga War was fought between Ashoka, the great Mauryan Emperor, and the ruler of the State of Kalinga.
▪️ It was seen as one of the most famous and the bloodiest battles in World history, as thousnds of people died in this war
▪️ In the **13th Rock Edict Ashoka** describes about the Kalinga war.

**Ashoka & Buddhism**
▪️ After the Kalinga War, Ashoka **embraced Buddhism**.
▪️ He gave up further wars, and decided to spread the message of love, peace, and non-violence. 
▪️ He converted to Buddhism and convened the **Third Buddhist Council** at Patliputra.
▪️ The **Third Buddhist Council** was held in **Pataliputra** (modern-day Patna) in **250 BCE** under the patronage of Emperor Ashoka and presided over by **Moggaliputta Tissa**.
▪️ In the Third Buddhist Council **Abhidhamma Pitaka** was compiled, which is about Buddhist philosophy.
▪️ Ashoka actively spread the message of Dhamma and even appointed special ministers called Dhamma Mahamatras to propagate it.

The Kalinga War was the pivotal event that led Emperor Ashoka to embrace Buddhism and renounce military conquest, dedicating himself to non-violence and spreading the concept of dharma (righteousness) for the rest of his reign.
((ih01EFHq8))

**Chanakya**
▪️ Other names are **Vishnugupta** and **Kautilya**.
▪️ Chanakya is also called ‘**Indian Machiavelli**”.
▪️ Teacher of Chandragupta Maurya, who was also his Chief Minister.
▪️ He was a teacher and scholar at Taxila. 
▪️ He was also a minister in the court of Bindusara.
▪️ He is credited to be the master strategist behind the usurping of the Nanda throne and the rise of the Mauryan Empire through his student, Chandragupta.
▪️ He wrote **Arthashastra** which mentioned about various aspects of Maurya administration.

children.string:
The disappearance of the Mauryas from the political map of India saw the emergence of many indigenous and foreign rulers, who divided north and south India and ruled over them for nearly five centuries.

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FK79SV992c1.png?alt=media&token=d8c9572e-e511-444d-b1b7-acdcf6489a37)

The eclipse of the Kushanas in North India and of the Satavahanas in the Deccan in the 3rd century CE resulted in a period of political disintegration. It paved the way for the emergence of several minor powers and new ruling families. It was against this background the Guptas laid the foundation of the empire. After the Mauryas, Guptas realized the political unification of North India and covered much of the Indian subcontinent. The Gupta Empire stretched across northern, central, and parts of southern India between 320 and 550 CE. This was how the Gupta Empire map looked at the end of the 4th century

blocks.string: **Gupta Empire Map**

children.string:
**Sri Gupta**
▪️ The founder of the Gupta dynasty was Sri Gupta.
▪️ He was succeeded by Ghatotkacha.
▪️ These two were called Maharajas.

**Chandragupta I (320 – 330 A.D.)**
▪️ Chandragupta I and was the first to be called Maharajadhiraja (the great king of kings).
▪️ He strengthened his position by a matrimonial alliance with the Licchavis.
▪️ He married Kumaradevi, a princess of that family.
▪️ The Mehrauli Iron Pillar inscription mentions his extensive conquests.
▪️ Chandragupta I is considered to be the first important ruler of the Gupta era which starts with his accession in A.D. 320.

**Samudragupta (330-380 A.D.)**
▪️ He was the greatest of the rulers of the Gupta dynasty.
▪️ His court poet was Harisena.
▪️ Harisena composed the  court Allahabad Pillar inscriptions
▪️ The Allahabad Pillar inscriptions provide a detailed account of Samudragupta’s reign.
▪️ He marched against the South Indian monarchs.
▪️ He issued gold and silver coins with the legend ‘restorer of the asvamedha’.
▪️ Because of his military achievements, Samudragupta was hailed as ‘**Indian Napoleon**’.

**Chandragupta II (380-415 A.D.)**
▪️ He was son of Samudragupta
▪️ He adopted the title  of "Vikramaditya".
▪️ Through matrimonial alliances, he strengthened his political power.
▪️ His fought war against the Saka satraps of western India.
▪️ After his victory, he performed the horse sacrifice and assumed the title Sakari, meaning, ‘destroyer of Sakas’. 
▪️ He also called himself ‘Vikramaditya’.

**Kumaragupta**
Kumaragupta was the son and successor of Chandragupta II.
A number of coins were issued and his inscriptions are found all over the Gupta Empire.
Kumaragupta also performed an asvamedha sacrifice.
Kumaragupta laid the foundation of Nalanda University which emerged as an institution of international reputation.
A powerful wealthy tribe called the ‘Pushyamitras’ defeated the Gupta army at the end of his reign.

**Skandagupta**
A branch of the Huns from Central Asia made attempts to cross the Hindukush mountains and invade India.
Skandagupta who really faced the Hun invasion.
He fought successfully against the Huns and saved the empire.

blocks.string: Rulers of Gupta Dynasty

The Delhi Sultanate marked a significant era in Indian history, lasting from A.D. 1206 to 1526, during which five different dynasties ruled over North India and parts of South India. The Sultanate brought extensive changes in society, administration, and culture.

**🏰 Dynasties of the Delhi Sultanate (1206–1526)**

The Delhi Sultanate ruled from 1206 to 1526 and consisted of five major dynasties:
1. Slave (Mamluk) Dynasty – 1206–1290
2. Khalji Dynasty – 1290–1320
3. Tughlaq Dynasty – 1320–1414
4. Sayyid Dynasty – 1414–1451
5. Lodi Dynasty – 1451–1526

🔑 Key Point
> The first four dynasties (Slave, Khalji, Tughlaq, Sayyid) were Turkish in origin.
> The Lodi Dynasty was the only Afghan dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate.

**Delhi Sultanate dynasties and their founders:**

1. Slave (Mamluk) Dynasty (1206–1290) -- Qutubuddin Aibak
2. Khalji Dynasty (1290–1320) -- Jalauddin Khilji
3. Tughlaq Dynasty (1320–1414) -- Giyazuddin Tughlaq
4. Sayyid Dynasty (1414–1451) -- Khizr Khan
5. Lodi Dynasty (1451–1526) -- Bulul Lodi

children.string:
After the death of Muhammad Ghori in 1206, Qutbuddin Aibak declared independence and established Slave dynasty. He was Turkish in origin. 
🔸 He made Lahore his capital. Delhi was then his military center. 
🔸 This led to the foundation of the Slave Dynasty.
🔸 Slave dynasty is also called as **Mamluk** Dynasty.
🔸 It was the first Muslim dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate.

➤ The Slave Dynasty consisted of three sub-dynasties:
🔹 1. Qutbi Dynasty (1206–1211), founded by Qutbuddin Aibak.
🔹 2. First Ilbari Dynasty (1211–1266), founded by Iltutmish.
🔹 3. Second Ilbari Dynasty (1266–1290), founded by Balban.

Thus we can say that slave dynasty ruled between 1206 till 1290.
Founded by **Qutbuddin Aibak**, a former slave and trusted general of Muhammad Ghori.

**Qutubuddin Aibak (1206 - 1210)**
▪️ He was a slave military general under Mohammad Ghori
▪️ After the death of Gohri in 2016, he declared him self as independent, and founded the slave dynasty in 1206.
▪️ **Lahore** was his capital. 
▪️ He was also known as **Lakh Baksh** for his generosity.
▪️ He patronized scholars like **Hasan Nizami**.
▪️ He build the city Mehrauli in Delhi. 
▪️ Later Iltutmish make Mehrauli, as the capital.
▪️ He died in 1210 after falling from horse while playing Polo.

**Qutub Minar**
▪️ Construction of Qutub Minar was started by Qutubuddin Aibak.
▪️ It is build on the Mehrauli city, Delhi.
▪️ It was named after the Sufi saint **Khwaja Qutbuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki**.
▪️ It was completed by Iltutmish
▪️ Later Alauddin Khilji build a gate, Alia Darwaza, for Qutub Minar.

**Quwatul-Islam mosque in Delhi**
▪️ Its construction was started by Qutubuddin Aibak.
▪️ It is build on the Mehrauli city, Delhi, adjacent to Qutub Minar.
▪️ It was completed by Iltutmish

**Dhaidin ka Jompra**
▪️ It was built (both started and completed )by Qutubuddin Aibak at Ajmer

🔹  Iltutmish was the real founder of Delhi Sultanate, as it was Iltutmish who shifted capital from Lahore to Delhi. 
🔹  He was a slave son-in-law of Qutubuddin Aibak. 
🔹 Mehrauli Delhi, city was built by Aibak, made the capital of Delhi Sultanate by Iltutmish. 
🔹 Created the ruling elite known as the **Chalisa** or **THE FORTY** (Group of Forty nobles).  It was later abolished by Balban.
🔹 He completed the construction of Qutub Minar and Quwattul-Islam mosque, which were started by Qutubuddin Aibak.

children.string:
**Brahmo Samaj**
▪️ Brahmo sabha was founded in 1828
▪️ It was founded by Raja Rammohan Roy, in 1828, in Calcutta.
▪️ In 1830 it was renamed as "Brahma Samaj"
▪️ Raja Rammohan Roy is also known as Father of Indian Renaissance
▪️ Gopal Krishna Gokhale called Raja Rammohan Roy the ‘Father of Modern India’.

**Core Ideas of Brahmo Samaj**
▪️ Belief in one God (monotheism).
▪️ Rejection of idol worship and rituals.
▪️ Opposed caste system and social evils (sati, polygamy, child marriage).
▪️ Brahmo Samaj played the key role in abolition of Sati in India. 
▪️ Promoted women’s education and widow remarriage.

**Influence:**
▪️ Brahmo Samaj based its ideas on the teachings of the Upanishads.

**Raja Rammohan Roy & Press Freedom**
▪️ Raja Rammohan Roy started his first Bengali language weekly newspaper, Sambad Koumudi, in 1918
▪️ His newspaper Sambad Koumudi helped people form an opinion about the issues affecting their daily life in British India.
▪️ In 1822, Roy published the journal Mirat-ul-Akbar in Persian.
▪️ It was Mughal ruler Akbar-II who gave the title of "Raja" to Raja Rammohan Roy.

**Arya Samaj**
▪️ Arya Samaj was founded by Swami Dayanand Saraswati in 1875 in Bombay.
▪️ Arya Samaj believed in the infallibility of the Vedas. 
▪️ Arya Samaj gave the slogan “Back to the Vedas”.

**Core Beliefs:**
▪️ Monotheism (belief in one God).
▪️ Rejection of idol worship, rituals, and priestly dominance.
▪️ Condemned caste system based on birth, but supported the caste system by occupation. 
▪️ Promoted equality of all human beings, including women.

**Social Reforms:**
▪️ Supported widow remarriage.
▪️ Opposed child marriage.
▪️ Promoted education for girls and boys alike.

** Educational Work:** 
▪️ Established Dayanand Anglo-Vedic (DAV) Schools & Colleges.

**Ramakrishna Mission**
▪️ It was founded in 1897 by Swami Vivekananda.
▪️ It was founded yo spread the teachings of Ramakrishna Paramhansa, guru of Swami Vivekananda. 
▪️ The phrase "service to man is service to God" was coined by Swami Vivekananda

**Teachings and Beliefs**
▪️ All religions lead to the same truth.
▪️ Service to man is service to God.
▪️ Promoted universal brotherhood and tolerance.
▪️ Condemned caste system and untouchability.

**Lord Dalhousie (1848–1856):**
▪️ Tenure: 1848–1856)
**Administrative Reforms:**
▪️ Introduced Doctrine of Lapse – annexed states with no natural heir (e.g., Satara, Jhansi, Nagpur).
▪️ Introduced centralized administration and improved railways, posts, and telegraphs.
▪️ Started the Public Works Department (PWD).
▪️ Introduced modern postal system (1854) and telegraph lines.
▪️ Started railways in India (1853) – first line between Bombay and Thane.
▪️ Reformed the education system – established universities and improved vernacular education.
▪️ Introduced wood’s despatch (1854) – “Magna Carta of English Education in India.”

**Territorial Expansion (Annexations):**
▪️ Punjab (1849) after the Second Anglo-Sikh War.
▪️ Sikkim, Lower Burma, Satara, Jhansi, Nagpur, Oudh (under Doctrine of Lapse or misrule).

**Other Works:**
▪️ Improved roads and canals for communication and irrigation.
▪️ Focused on economic development and military modernization.

**Criticism:**
▪️ The Doctrine of Lapse caused widespread resentment.
▪️ His policies were a major cause leading to the Revolt of 1857.

children.string:
**Vernacular Press Act, 1778**
▪️ It was enacted by Lytton in 1778.
▪️ This act banned publications of the vernacular language newspapers (local language newspaper). 
▪️ It was repealed by Ripon in 1782.

**Factories Acts:**
▪️ First Factories Act, 1881 was passed during the tenure of Lord Ripon
▪️ Second Factories Act, 1891 was passed during the tenure of Lord Lansdowne
▪️ Third Factories Act, 1911 was passed during the tenure of Lord Hardinge-II

**Factories Act of 1881**
▪️ Child labor: Prohibited children under seven from working and limited those between seven and twelve to a maximum of nine hours a day. 
▪️ Safety: Mandated that dangerous machinery be properly fenced to prevent accidents. 
▪️ Holidays: Required four holidays per month for children. 
▪️ Scope: Primarily focused on child labor and safety, and only applied to factories with 100 or more workers.

**Factories Act of 1891**
▪️ Child labor: Raised the minimum age for employment to nine years. 
▪️ Weekly rest: Introduced the concept of a weekly holiday for all workers, not just children. 
▪️ Working hours: Set a maximum of 11 hours per day for women and applied regulations to adult workers as well. 
▪️ Scope: Expanded the scope of the previous act by applying it to factories with 50 or more workers and adding new regulations for women and children.

**Factories Act 1911**
▪️ Reduced adult working hours to 12 per day (including rest intervals).
▪️ Mandated holidays and annual leave.
▪️ Improved safety measures, like better machinery guards.
▪️ Increased inspector powers and fines for violations.
