blocks.string: Connected Blocks
**Mahatma Gandhi Important Events:**

**In South Africa (1893–1914)**

1893:
▪️ Gandhi went to South Africa to fight a case of Indian merchant Abdullah Khan, and faced racial discrimination.
▪️ On June 7, he was ^^thrown out of a first-class train compartment at Pietermaritzburg^^.

1894:
▪️ Founded the ^^Natal Indian Congress^^ to fight for the rights of Indians.

1899:
▪️ Formed the ^^Indian Ambulance Corps^^ during the Boer War.

1904:
▪️ Started the magazine Indian Opinion and established the Phoenix Farm near Durban.

1906:
▪️ Led his ^^first Civil Disobedience Movement^^ (Satyagraha) against the Asiatic Ordinance in Transvaal.

1907:
▪️ Continued Satyagraha against the Compulsory Registration Law for Asians, known as the ^^Black Act^^, in Transvaal.

1908:
▪️ Was tried and ^^imprisoned for the first time^^ in Johannesburg Jail.

1910:
▪️ Founded Tolstoy Farm near Johannesburg, later known as Gandhi Ashram.

1913:
▪️ Started ^^Satyagraha against the law that cancelled recognition of non-Christian marriages in Cape Town^^.

1914:
▪️ Returned to India and was ^^awarded the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal for his service during the Boer War^^.

**In India (1915–1930)**

1915:
▪️ Returned to India (arrived in Bombay on January 9).
▪️ Founded the Satyagraha Ashram at Kocharab near Ahmedabad on May 20. In 1917, the Ashram was shifted to the banks of the Sabarmati River.
▪️ Began his all-India tour.

1916:
▪️ Delivered a speech at the opening ceremony of Banaras Hindu University (BHU) on February 4.
▪️ Did not take part in active politics but attended the Lucknow Session of the Indian National Congress (December 26–30).
▪️ At this session, ^^Raj Kumar Shukla from Bihar requested him to visit Champaran^^.

1917:
▪️ Entered active politics with the Champaran campaign to help the indigo farmers of Bihar.
▪️ ^^Champaran Satyagraha^^ became his ^^first Civil Disobedience Movement^^ in India.

1918:
▪️ Launched the ^^Ahmedabad Mill Strike^^ to support industrial workers in February and used hunger strike as a protest for the first time. It was Gandhis ^^first Hunger Strike^^
▪️ In March, led the Kheda Satyagraha for farmers who could not pay rent due to crop failure.
▪️ ^^Kheda Satyagraha was his first Non-Cooperation Movement^^.

1919:
▪️ Called for ^^Satyagraha against the Rowlatt Act^^ on April 6.
▪️ ^^Returned the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal^^ in protest against the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (April 13).
▪️ Elected ^^President of the All India Khilafat Conference^^ in November (Delhi).

1920–22:
▪️ Led the Non-Cooperation and Khilafat Movements (August 1920 – February 1922).
Called off the movement on February 12, 1922, after the ^^Chauri-Chaura incident^^ (February 5).
▪️ This was the first mass-based political movement under Gandhi.

1924:
▪️ ^^Presided over the Belgaum Session^^ of the Indian National Congress — the only time he became Congress President.

1925–27:
▪️ Retired temporarily from politics and focused on the constructive programme of the Congress.
▪️ Returned to active politics in 1927.

**In India (1930–1948)**
1930–34:
▪️ Launched the ^^Civil Disobedience Movement^^ with the ^^Dandi March^^ (Salt Satyagraha).
▪️ First Phase: March 12, 1930 – March 5, 1931.
▪️ Signed the ^^Gandhi–Irwin Pact^^ on March 5, 1931.
▪️ ^^Attended the Second Round Table Conference^^ in London (September 7 – December 1, 1931).
▪️ Second Phase: January 3, 1932 – April 17, 1934.
▪️ In 1930, Time magazine named him “^^Man of the Year^^.”
▪️  Mahatma Gandhi founded the ^^All India Anti-Untouchability League^^ in September 1932, which was later renamed the Harijan Sevak Sangh (Servants of Untouchables Society)
1934–39:
▪️ Retired again from active politics and established Sevagram (Wardha Ashram).

1939:
▪️ Resumed active politics.

1940–41:
▪️ Launched the ^^Individual Satyagraha Movement^^.

1942:
▪️ Started the ^^Quit India Movement^^ with the slogan “^^Do or Die^^” (August 9).
▪️ Gandhi and other Congress leaders were arrested.

1942–44:
▪️ Detained at Aga Khan Palace, Pune (August 9, 1942 – May 1944).
▪️ His wife Kasturba and secretary Mahadev Desai died during this period.
▪️ This was his last imprisonment.

1945:
▪️ Gandhi’s influence in the Congress started to decline.

1946:
▪️ Tried to stop communal violence in Noakhali (East Bengal) and Calcutta after the Muslim League’s Direct Action call.

1947:
▪️ Distressed by the Partition Plan announced on June 3.
Stayed in Calcutta to stop communal riots and observed silence on India’s Independence Day (August 15).
▪️ Returned to Delhi in September.

1948:
▪️ ^^Assassinated by Nathuram Godse^^ on January 30 at Birla House, New Delhi.
His last words were “Hey Ram.”

A collection of billions of stars is called a **galaxy**. 
There are billions of galaxies in the universe, each with different shapes e.g Spiral, Circular etc. 
The galaxy that contains our Sun is called the **Milky Way Galaxy** (or Aakash Ganga).
Milky way galaxy is spiral in shape. 
The Milky Way was discovered by **Galileo**. 
At the center of the Milky Way Galaxy, there is a black hole known as **Sagittarius A**.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FCxY7cDubx3.png?alt=media&token=3f3c7429-b9fa-42a2-b0a7-6f1d3c91bbdc)

The study of the universe is called **Cosmology**. 
The objects in the universe are known as **celestial bodies**. The three main types of celestial bodies are stars, planets, and satellites.
**Stars:** These have their own heat and light, such as the Sun.
**Planets:** These are bodies that revolve around a star, such as Earth.
**Satellites:** These are bodies that revolve around a planet, such as the Moon.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FV729jD2PcN.png?alt=media&token=ca5aea40-bea8-4aaf-a451-6ed28ec32dc0)

**About Sun**
▪️ Stars are celestial bodies that produce their own heat (energy) and light. 
▪️ Our Sun is a star in the Milky Way Galaxy. 
▪️ Sun is primarily composed of hydrogen (H) and helium (He). 
▪️ Inside the Sun, two hydrogen atoms come together and fuse to form helium in a process called **fusion**. This fusion occurs due to the high pressure and temperature in the Sun's core. 
▪️ The radiation (heat and light) from the Sun is a result of this fusion of hydrogen atoms into helium. 
▪️ Sunlight takes approximately 8 minutes to reach the surface of the Earth.
▪️ The nearest star to the Sun is called "**Proxima Centauri**".

**About Stars**
▪️ A group of stars that forms a recognisable pattern in the night sky is called as **constellation**. 
▪️ These patterns are often named after mythological characters, animals, or objects. 
▪️ The two major constellations are Ursa Major and Ursa Minor.
▪️ **Ursa Major**, also known as the Great Bear, is one of the most well-known constellations. It is visible throughout the year in most of the northern hemisphere. 
▪️ **Ursa Minor**, also known as the Little Bear, is another prominent constellation. It includes Polaris, also known as the **North  (Pole)Star**, which is located almost directly above the North Pole.

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F2CBFWgQONf.png?alt=media&token=e7903a1f-ed2c-4aeb-80b7-4fd6937f7deb)

children.string:
**Solar System Components**
▪️ The Sun and the planets that orbit it form the Solar System. 
▪️ There are eight planets that revolve around the Sun in elliptical orbits. 

**The eight planets are: **
▪️ Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. 
▪️ The first four planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars) are called terrestrial planets.
▪️ The last four (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune) are known as gas giants or Jovian planets. 

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FqBhFui2GBC.png?alt=media&token=c5563c15-cd8e-4648-838f-94050a13d942)

**Asteroids**
▪️ Between Mars and Jupiter, there is a region that contains numerous asteroids, known as the **Asteroid Belt**. 
▪️ In the Asteroid belt the largest astroid is **Ceres**
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FMWEFwZSOut.png?alt=media&token=72fb5f05-38d8-4c0d-874b-6f6ddae21a61)

Largest planet: Jupiter
Smallest planet: Mercury
Fastest planet (revolution): Mercury (88 days)
Fastest planet (rotation): Jupiter (9 hours, 55 minutes)
Slowest planet (rotation): Venus (243 days)
Hottest planet: Venus

Size wise (ascending order): Mercury, Mars, Venus, Earth, Neptune, Uranus, Saturn, and Jupiter. Jupiter is the largest planet.

▪️ All planets rotate counterclockwise (from top view) or from west to east (side view) except for Venus and Uranus, which rotate clockwise or from east to west. 
▪️ Earth rotates from west to east, and that is why we feel Sun rises from east and sets in the west.

**Mercury:** 
▪️ Mercury is the nearest planet to the Sun. 
▪️ It is the fastest planet in terms of revolution around the Sun, taking only 88 days. 
▪️ It has no satellites.

**Venus:** 
▪️ Venus is the second nearest planet to the Sun after Mercury.
▪️ Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system because its atmosphere contains a lot of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas. 
Venus is also called Earth's twin because it is similar in shape and size to Earth. 
▪️ It has no natural satellites. 
▪️ Uranus and Venus are the only planets that rotate from east to west, while the rest rotate from west to east.
▪️ The Venus is slowest (in rotation) planet on the solar system, and thus its day (243 earth day) is longer than it year(225 earth days).

**Earth:** 
▪️ Earth is the only planet in the Solar System where life exists. 
▪️ It is also called the "Blue Planet" due to its appearance from space. 
▪️ It has one satellite, the Moon. 
▪️ The earth is 150 million KM away from the Sun.

**Mars:** 
▪️ Mars is known as the "Red Planet" because of the presence of iron oxide (rust) in its soil, which gives it its reddish color. 
▪️ It is also called as Martian planet.
▪️ It has two satellites, Phobos and Deimos. 
▪️ The highest peak in the Solar System, Olympus Mons, is present in Mars and is a volcano located on Mars.

**Jupiter:** 
▪️ It is the largest planet in the Solar System. 
▪️ It has highest number of satellites (92) known natural satellites.
▪️ Ganymede is the largest natural satellite of Jupiter as well as in the entire Solar System.
**Saturn:** It has 83 known satellites. Titan is the largest moon of Saturn.

blocks.string: Solar System

children.string:
The Earth revolves around the Sun in an elliptical orbit.
This means that the distance between the Earth and the Sun changes throughout the year. 
Our earth completed one revolution around Sun in **265 days and 6 hours**, and thus after every four years we have one extra day in the month of Feburary and that year is called as **leap year**. 
This revolution of earth around the sun is responsible for the changing seasons.

**Aphelion:** The point in Earth's orbit where it is farthest from the Sun. This occurs around early July 4th each year, and the distance is about 152 million KMs

**Perihelion:** The point in Earth's orbit where it is closest to the Sun. This occurs around early January 3rd each year, and the distance is about 147 million KMs.

On average the earth is 150 million KM away from the Sun.

The earth is tilted by 23.5 degree, and thus due to this tilting of earth on its plane we have the tropic of cancer (23.5 degree N) and tropic of capricorn (23.5 degree S)  latitudes. 
This is because at any time in the year the direct rays of earth falls on any latitude between tropic of cancer and capricorn, and thus the region between To cancer and To capricorn receives highest insolation, and is called as **torrid region**.  
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F4koIr-UM_T.png?alt=media&token=5ed06617-c314-4c3c-b9bf-a646f5ee4aac)

Latitudes:
90 degree N: North pole
66.5 degree N: Artic Circle
23.5 degree N: tropic of cancer
23.5 degree S: tropic of capricorn
66.5 degree S: Antarctic circle
90 degree S: South pole
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FDQv_j_O8is.png?alt=media&token=21247dfe-35a9-4954-8f43-a9ad92f9546d)

When the Suns rays falls direct on the tropic of cancer, it is called **summer solstice**, and it occurs on June 21, the longest day in the north hemisphere. It is called summer solstice because that time it is summer in norther hemisphere. 
June 21: national Yoga day, Summer Solstice

When the Suns rays falls direct on the tropic of Capricorn, it is called **winter solstice**, and it occurs on Dec 21, the shortest day (longest night) in the north hemisphere.  It is called winter solstice because that time it is winter in northern hemisphere.

When the vertical rays of Sun falls directly over equator it is called **equinox**, and it happens twice, once in March 21-22 (Spring season = Vernal (Spring) Equinox ) and once in Sept 22-23 (autum season = Autumnal (Fall) Equinox ). 
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FxQVW2CaUwz.png?alt=media&token=b9246bbc-e320-4fa6-abd7-a30c221facb7)

The the primary cause of the weathers i.e summer, autumm, winter and sprint is the revolution of earth (as well as the titled nature of the earth.)

children.string:
The Earth rotates on its axis once approximately every 24 hours. This rotation is from west to east, which is why the Sun appears to rise in the east and set in the west.

**Axial Tilt:** The Earth's axis is tilted at an angle of about 23.5 degrees relative to its orbital plane around the Sun. This tilt remains constant as the Earth orbits the Sun.

**Day and Night Cycle:** The primary cause of day and night is the Earth's rotation. As the Earth rotates, different parts of the surface move into and out of the Sun's light.

blocks.string: Rotation of Earth around its won axis.

children.string:
**About Moon**
▪️ The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite. 
▪️ It is the fifth largest moon in the Solar System.
▪️ It is the largest natural satellite relative to the size of its planet. 
▪️ The approximate average distance between the Earth and the Moon is 384,400 kilometers (or 238,855 miles). This is also known as one lunar distance and is the average of the Moon's elliptical orbit, which means the distance varies between its closest point (perigee) and farthest point (apogee)

**Synchronous Rotation:** 
▪️ The moon takes the same amount of time to rotate on its axis as it does to orbit the Earth. 
▪️ This period is approximately 27.3 days.

**Same Face Always Seen:** 
▪️ Because the rotation period and the orbital period are the same, the same side of the Moon always faces the Earth. 
▪️ This phenomenon is known as tidal locking.

**New Moon:** 
▪️ During the new moon phase, the Moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun. 
▪️ The side of the Moon facing Earth is not illuminated by the Sun, making it invisible in the night sky.

**Full Moon:** 
▪️ The full moon phase occurs when the Earth is between the Moon and the Sun. 
▪️ The side of the Moon facing Earth is fully illuminated, making it appear as a bright, complete circle.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FXdFuqHlxqI.png?alt=media&token=04135d49-ea22-4b49-b01e-43f25b45cd7d)

**Apogee:** Apogee is the point in the Moon's elliptical orbit where it is farthest from the Earth. At apogee, the Moon appears smaller in the sky.
**Perigee:** Perigee is the point in the Moon's elliptical orbit where it is closest to the Earth. At perigee, the Moon appears larger in the sky.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FBsN_XCpyNM.png?alt=media&token=61ca0632-ef20-4988-981e-844608dff4ce)

**Supermoon:** A supermoon occurs when a full moon or a new moon coincides with perigee, the point at which the Moon is closest to the Earth. This results in the Moon appearing larger and brighter than usual.
**Micromoon:** A micromoon occurs when a full moon or a new moon coincides with apogee, the point at which the Moon is farthest from the Earth. This results in the Moon appearing smaller and dimmer than usual.

Venus, the second planet from the Sun with a thick, toxic atmosphere. 
It's often called **Earth's "evil twin"** due to its similar size and rocky composition, but vastly different conditions. Venus experiences a runaway greenhouse effect, making it the **hottest planet in our solar system**, with surface temperatures hot enough to melt lead.

children.string:
**About Indus River:**
▪️ The ancient name of Jhelum was "Sindhu".
▪️ It originates from Bokharchu glacier, near Mansarovar lake, in Kailash range, in Karakoram range, Tibet.
▪️ Leh city is situated on the bank of Indus. 
▪️ From Mansarovar lake, Indus rivers runs southwards, but near the Mt. Naga Parbat, it takes southward direction. 
▪️ Indus has fiver major tributries i.e Jhelum, Chenab, Rabi, Beas and Satluj.
▪️ All the **fiver major tributries** i.e Jhelum, Chenab, Rabi, Beas and Satluj, joins and forms Panjnad, which then merges with Indus at Mithankot. 

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2Ff-spvR_SaB.png?alt=media&token=b0265180-06d1-4101-9a63-284077719bd6)

**Mention of Indus River in Rig Veda**
▪️ The rig veda mentions of the "sapta sindhu" means seven rivers, which are Indus and its tributries. 

**Their Ancient Names  were:**
▪️ Indus --- Sindhu
▪️ Jhelum -- Vitasta
▪️ Chenab -- Askini
▪️ Ravi -- Purushni or Iravati
▪️ Beas -- Bipasa or Vipasa ( B--B)
▪️ Satluj -- Shatadru or Shutudri (S--S)
▪️ Ghaggar -- Saraswati (it has disappeared)  

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2Fpm7eDrpsF_.png?alt=media&token=500dbebf-b7d8-45c9-b4f6-4cb898801e15)

**Jhelum river:**
▪️ The ancient name of Jhelum was "Vitasta".
▪️ It originates from Verinag, in Pirpanjal range.
▪️ It flows through the Srinagar city.
▪️ Important lakes that falls on its course are: Dal lake, Wullar lake, Nigeen lake etc.

((NIwFSRzGw))
![ jhelum river image notes ](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2FMehboobElahi%2Fb-n48EsVMp.png?alt=media&token=9276a452-37bb-46e7-8a58-5014b461236e)

**Chenab river:**
▪️ The ancient name of Chenab was "Askini".
▪️ It originates from Baralacha pass.

**Ravi river:**
▪️ The ancient name of Ravi was "Purushni or Iravati".
▪️ It originates from Rhotang pass. (also Beas river)
---
▪️ The "Harappa" site was situated on the bank of Ravi river.

**Beas river:**
▪️ The ancient name of Beas was "Bipasa".
▪️ It originates from Rhotang pass. (also Ravi river)
▪️ It merges with Satluj river at Harike, in Punjab, India.
▪️ It is the only major tributary of Indus that originates as well as ends within India.

**Satluj river:**
▪️ The ancient name of Satluj was "Shutudri".
▪️ It originates from Mansarovar lake, in Kailash range in Tibet.
▪️ It enters India, Himachal Pradesh, through Shipkla pass. 
▪️ It is the only major tributary of Indus, that does not originates from India.

**Shoyk river:**
▪️ Shyok river is a minor tributary of Indus. 
▪️ It originates from Siachen glacier.
▪️ It flows through the Nubra valley, Ladakh and finally joins Indus in Gilgit Baldistan. 
----
▪️ Other minor tributries of Indus river are Shingo, Suru, Zanskar etc.

**Indus Water Treaty**
▪️ It was signed in 1960, between India and Pakistan
▪️ It was brokered by World Bank
▪️ It divided Indus and its tributries into two groups.
▪️ Water of Indus, Jhelum and Chenab were given to Pakistan
▪️ Water of Ravi, Beas and Satluj were given to India

Greenhouse gases **absorb infrared radiation (net heat energy) emitted from Earth’s surface and reradiating it back to Earth’s surface.**
**In 1992, The Kyoto Protocol** is an international treaty of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) that commits state **parties to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.**

**The Kyoto Protocol**
▪️ It was adopted in 1997 under the the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
▪️ It is related to climate change i.e to reduce emission of greenhouse gases.
▪️ The Kyoto Protocol applied to the seven greenhouse gases listed in Annex A: carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), nitrogen trifluoride (NF3)

Straits

Definition: A narrow passage of water connecting two larger bodies of water, often critical for maritime trade.
Important Straits:

Gibraltar:

Connects: Atlantic Ocean to Mediterranean Sea.
Location: Between southern Spain and northern Morocco.
Significance: Controls access to the Mediterranean; key for European and African trade routes.


Malacca:

Connects: Indian Ocean to South China Sea (Pacific Ocean).
Location: Between Malay Peninsula and Sumatra (Indonesia).
Significance: One of the busiest shipping lanes, vital for global trade (oil, goods).


Bab-el-Mandeb:

Connects: Red Sea to Gulf of Aden (Indian Ocean).
Location: Between Yemen and Djibouti/Eritrea.
Significance: Critical for oil shipments from the Persian Gulf to Europe via the Suez Canal.


Hormuz:

Connects: Persian Gulf to Gulf of Oman (Indian Ocean).
Location: Between Iran and Oman.
Significance: Major chokepoint for global oil exports (about 20% of world’s oil passes through).

Isthmus

Definition: A narrow strip of land connecting two larger landmasses, with water on both sides.
Important Isthmuses:

Isthmus of Panama:

Location: Connects North and South America.
Significance: Home to the Panama Canal, linking Atlantic and Pacific Oceans for trade.


Isthmus of Suez:

Location: Connects Africa and Asia (Egypt).
Significance: Site of the Suez Canal, a vital shipping route between Europe and Asia.


Isthmus of Kra:

Location: Southern Thailand, connecting Malay Peninsula to mainland Asia.
Significance: Potential site for a canal to shorten maritime routes in Southeast Asia.

▪️ Location: Northwest Africa (Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia).
▪️ Length: ~2,500 km.
▪️ Highest Peak: Toubkal, Morocco (4,167 m / 13,671 ft).



**Ural**
▪️ Location: Russia (divides Europe and Asia).
▪️ Length: ~2,500 km (Arctic Ocean to Caspian Sea region).
▪️ Highest Peak: Mount Narodnaya, Russia (1,894 m / 6,214 ft).

**Drakensberg**
Location: Southern Africa (South Africa, Lesotho).

**Altai**
▪️ Location: Central Asia (Russia, China, Mongolia, Kazakhstan).
▪️ Length: ~2,000 km.
▪️ Highest Peak: Belukha Mountain, Russia/Kazakhstan (4,506 m / 14,784 ft).


**Himalayas**
Location: South Asia (India, Nepal, Bhutan, China, Pakistan).
Length: ~2,400 km.
Highest Peak: Mount Everest, Nepal (8,848 m / 29,029 ft).

**Great Dividing Range**
Location: Eastern Australia.
Length: ~3,500 km (Queensland to Victoria).
Highest Peak: Mount Kosciuszko, Australia (2,228 m / 7,310 ft).

**Colombia’s Unique Feature:**

Colombia is the only South American country with coastlines on both the Atlantic Ocean (Caribbean Sea) and the Pacific Ocean.
Borders:

Atlantic (north): Via Caribbean Sea coastline.
Pacific (west): Direct Pacific coastline.


Significance: Strategic location for trade and maritime activities.

blocks.string: South America Continent

**Longest Lake**
▪️ Name: Lake Tanganyika
▪️ Location: Central Africa (Tanzania, DRC, Burundi, Zambia)
▪️ Note: Second deepest and second oldest lake; home to 350+ fish species.


**Deepest Lake**
▪️ Name: Lake Baikal
▪️ Location: Siberia, Russia
▪️ Note: Contains ~20% of world’s unfrozen freshwater; oldest lake (~25–30 million years).

**Largest Lake (by Surface Area)**
▪️ Name: Caspian Sea
▪️ Location: Eurasia (Russia, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Iran, Azerbaijan)



**Largest Freshwater Lake (by Area)**
▪️ Lake Superior
▪️ USA–Canada (Great Lakes)



**Largest Lake by Volume**
▪️ Name: Lake Baikal
▪️ Volume: 23,615 km³
▪️ Note: Holds ~20% of world’s liquid freshwater — more than all Great Lakes combined.


**Highest Lake**
▪️ Name: Lake Titicaca
▪️ Location: Peru–Bolivia border (Andes)
▪️ Note: Largest lake in South America by volume and area; sacred to Incas.


**Largest Desert Lake**
▪️ Name: Lake Turkana
▪️ Location: Kenya–Ethiopia (Great Rift Valley)

**RBI (Reserve Bank of India)**
▪️ Founded April 1, 1935, under RBI Act 1934; 
▪️ HQ in Mumbai (shifted from Kolkata in 1937); 
▪️ Nationalized in 1949.
▪️ Current Governor: Sanjay Malhotra (appointed Dec 2024; oversees monetary policy & banking regs).

**Core Functions:**
▪️ Issue & manage currency (regulates money supply).
▪️ Formulate & implement monetary policy (e.g., repo rate, CRR, SLR to control inflation & growth).
▪️ Banker to govt (manages public debt, accounts).
▪️ Regulator of banks & NBFCs
▪️ Forex management
▪️ Promotes financial inclusion 
▪️ Bank of last resort for bankers

**SEBI (Securities & Exchange Board of India)**
▪️ Set up Apr 12, 1988 (statutory powers via SEBI Act 1992); 
▪️ HQ in Mumbai; 
▪️ Under Ministry of Finance.
▪️ Current Chairman: Tuhin Kanta Pandey.


**Core Functions:**
▪️ Regulate stock exchanges, brokers, mutual funds, depositories.
▪️ Prevent unfair practices (insider trading, fraud).
▪️ Promote investor education & market development.
▪️ Ensure transparency in disclosures & listings.

**Economic Fullforms:**
▪️ RBI: Reserve Bank of India
▪️ SEBI: Security and Exchange Board of India
▪️ UPI: Unified Payments Interface
▪️ ATM: Automatic Teller Machine
▪️ FDI: Foreign Direct Investment
▪️ IBC: Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code
▪️ IBBI: Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India
▪️ GST: Goods & Services Tax

**SAARC**
▪️ South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation
▪️ Established in 1985
▪️ Total members 8: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.
▪️ Headquarter is at Katamandu, Nepal
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FwRS9PegrWu.png?alt=media&token=9c2ba236-a3b1-4b26-a0fb-919d5f93e14c)

**BIMSTEC**
▪️ Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation
▪️ Established in 1997
▪️ Total members 7: Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and Thailand
▪️ Headquarter is at Dhaka, Bangladesh
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FvCraf1VOKk.png?alt=media&token=bb5462c5-86a3-4e68-a8c1-bbdcb110e4b9)

**ASEAN**
▪️ Association of Southeast Asian Nations
▪️ ASEAN was established on August 8, 1967 by Bangkok declaration.
▪️ The five founding members of ASEAN wer: Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand ( mnemonics: ITS 5 PM )
▪️ Total members today 10:  Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.
▪️ Headquarter is at Jakarta, Indonesia
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FLUdMS7OnLl.png?alt=media&token=39065e86-2638-42c0-ab3c-a0522322f696)

**NATO**
▪️ North Atlantic Treaty Organization
▪️ It is an intergovernmental military alliance.
▪️ Founded in the aftermath of World War II, NATO was established with the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty in 1949
▪️ If was founded in 1949, by 12 founding members. 
▪️ As of Aug 2025, NATO has **32 members**. The latest member is Sweden.
▪️ NATO's main administrative headquarter is in Brussels, Belgium.
▪️ Its military headquarters is in Mons, Belgium

**Collective Defence**
▪️ The principle of collective defence – Article 5 of the NATO treaty states:
👉 “An attack on one member is considered an attack on all members.”

**Operation Enduring Freedom (2001):**
▪️ Launched after the 9/11 attacks.
▪️ NATO invoked Article 5 for the first time.
▪️ Military operations in Afghanistan to dismantle Al-Qaeda and remove the Taliban.

**National Emblem of India**
Video: {video:0mAPyZvvXt4:0}
▪️ The State Emblem of India is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Ashoka at Sarnath.
▪️ It was erected by Ashoka at Sarnath in around 250BC
▪️ Adopted on 26 January 1950 (the day India became a Republic).
▪️ It consists of four Asiatic lions standing back-to-back.
▪️ Out of four lions, only three are visible (the fourth is hidden).

Below the lions, there is a circular base featuring:
A horse on the left.
A bull on the right.
The Dharma Chakra (wheel) in the center.
An elephant and a lion carved on the abacus.

The motto inscribed below in Devanagari script:
“Satyameva Jayate” (Truth Alone Triumphs) — taken from the Mundaka Upanishad.

It is used on all official documents, currency notes, passports, and government buildings.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FnUAKrMNn4N.png?alt=media&token=d5a463a8-f6a3-4690-bfe4-0c6bdeadaa1b)

5. Odissi – Odisha

page_title: 60 Important Rules of Grammar | By Rani Maam

blocks.string: Video credit to: [English With Rani Mam](https://www.youtube.com/@EnglishWithRaniMam)

children.string:
2. Nobody → Nothing
Rule: Use "nothing" for objects or things when the subject is "nobody".
Example:
Nobody found nothing interesting in the movie.
(No person found any interesting thing.)
3. Somebody → Something
Rule: Use "something" for objects or things when the subject is "somebody".
Example:
Somebody brought something for you.
(A person brought an item for you.)
4. Anybody → Anything
Rule: Use "anything" for objects or things when the subject is "anybody".
Example:
Anybody can do anything if they try hard.
(Any person can accomplish any task.)
Key Points:
"Everybody," "Nobody," "Somebody," "Anybody" → refer to people.
"Everything," "Nothing," "Something," "Anything" → refer to things or objects.

Practise vs Practice
Practise (Verb): To do something repeatedly to improve.
Example: You should practise batting daily.
Practice (Noun): The act of doing something regularly.
Example: Cricket practice starts at 6 AM.

**Advice vs Advise**
Advice (Noun): Suggestion or recommendation.
Example: His advice helped me score a century.
Advise (Verb): To give suggestion.
Example: The coach advised him to play defensively.

Complain vs Complaint
Complain (Verb): To express dissatisfaction.
Example: Fans complain about poor umpiring.
Complaint (Noun): A statement of dissatisfaction.
Example: He filed a complaint against the decision.

Affect vs Effect
Affect (Verb): To influence.
Example: Rain affected the match.
Effect (Noun/Verb): Result / To bring about.
Example: The effect was a draw.

**Assure vs Ensure vs Insure**
Assure (Verb): To promise or reassure.
Example: He assured the team of victory.
Ensure (Verb): To make certain.
Example: Ensure you wear helmet.
Insure (Verb): To protect financially (insurance).
Example: Insure your bat against damage.

Hear vs Listen
Hear (Verb): To perceive sound.
Example: I heard the crowd cheer.
Listen (Verb): To pay attention to sound.
Example: Listen to the coach carefully.

Heal vs Heel
Heal (Verb): To cure or recover.
Example: The injury will heal in a week.
Heel (Noun): Back part of foot.
Example: He was hit on the heel.

Prescribe vs Proscribe
Prescribe (Verb): To recommend (medicine).
Example: Doctor prescribed rest.
Proscribe (Verb): To prohibit.
Example: Betting is proscribed in cricket.

Adopt vs Adapt vs Adept
Adopt (Verb): To take up legally.
Example: They adopt new batting technique.
Adapt (Verb): To adjust.
Example: Adapt to spin bowling.
Adept (Adjective): Skilled.
Example: He is adept at cover drive.

Allude vs Elude
Allude (Verb): To refer indirectly.
Example: He alluded to his century.
Elude (Verb): To escape.
Example: The ball eluded the fielder.

Amend vs Emend
Amend (Verb): To improve or change (law).
Example: They amended the playing rules.
Emend (Verb): To correct (text).
Example: The scorecard was emended.

Bought vs Brought
Bought (V. of buy): Purchased.
Example: He bought a new bat.
Brought (V. of bring): Carried.
Example: He brought lunch to the ground.

Compose vs Comprise
Compose (Verb): To make up.
Example: The team is composed of 11 players.
Comprise (Verb): To include.
Example: The team comprises 11 players.

Deface vs Efface
Deface (Verb): To spoil appearance.
Example: Someone defaced the stadium wall.
Efface (Verb): To erase.
Example: He effaced the mistake from the board.

Deprecate vs Depreciate
Deprecate (Verb): To disapprove.
Example: He deprecated sledging.
Depreciate (Verb): To reduce in value.
Example: Old bats depreciate fast.

Envelop vs Envelope
Envelop (Verb): To wrap or cover.
Example: Fog enveloped the stadium.
Envelope (Noun): Paper cover.
Example: Put the ticket in an envelope.

Excite vs Incite
Excite (Verb): To arouse interest.
Example: The match excited the crowd.
Incite (Verb): To provoke.
Example: He incited the fans to boo.

Flout vs Flaunt
Flout (Verb): To disobey openly.
Example: He flouted the no-ball rule.
Flaunt (Verb): To show off.
Example: He flaunted his new bat.

Hoard vs Horde
Hoard (Verb/Noun): To store secretly.
Example: He hoards old cricket balls.
Horde (Noun): Large group.
Example: A horde of fans rushed in.

Loathe vs Loath
Loathe (Verb): To hate.
Example: I loathe losing.
Loath (Adjective): Reluctant.
Example: He is loath to bowl in death overs.

Lose vs Loose
Lose (Verb): To misplace or fail.
Example: Don't lose the match.
Loose (Adjective): Not tight.
Example: His grip was loose.

Mitigate vs Militate
Mitigate (Verb): To lessen.
Example: Rain gear mitigates discomfort.
Militate (Verb): To oppose (with against).
Example: Injury militates against performance.

Pour vs Pore
Pour (Verb): To flow.
Example: Rain poured during the match.
Pore (Verb): To study closely.
Example: He pored over the scorecard.

Proceed vs Precede
Proceed (Verb): To continue.
Example: Proceed to the next over.
Precede (Verb): To come before.
Example: Warm-up precedes the match.

Pray vs Prey
Pray (Verb): To request spiritually.
Example: Fans pray for victory.
Prey (Noun/Verb): Victim / To hunt.
Example: Bowlers prey on weak batsmen.

Rout vs Route
Rout (Verb/Noun): Defeat badly.
Example: India routed Australia.
Route (Noun): Path.
Example: The team took a new route to the stadium.

Censor vs Censure
Censor (Verb): To suppress content.
Example: They censored the controversial ad.
Censure (Verb): To criticize strongly.
Example: The board censured the player.

Wave vs Waive
Wave (Noun/Verb): Hand gesture / Ocean movement.
Example: Fans wave flags.
Waive (Verb): To give up right.
Example: He waived the follow-on.

Tow vs Toe
Tow (Verb/Noun): To pull.
Example: The car was towed away.
Toe (Noun): Part of foot.
Example: He stepped on my toe.

Site vs Sight vs Cite
Site (Noun): Location.
Example: The match site was changed.
Sight (Noun): Vision.
Example: The six was a beautiful sight.
Cite (Verb): To quote.
Example: He cited the rule correctly.

Diffuse vs Defuse
Diffuse (Verb): To spread.
Example: Rumors diffused quickly.
Defuse (Verb): To calm tension.
Example: Captain defused the argument.

Desert vs Dessert
Desert (Noun/Verb): Sandy area / To abandon.
Example: He deserted the team.
Dessert (Noun): Sweet dish.
Example: Ice cream is a popular dessert.

Sever vs Severe
Sever (Verb): To cut off.
Example: He severed ties with the coach.
Severe (Adjective): Serious.
Example: The injury was severe.

See vs Look vs Stare vs Peep vs Glare vs Glow vs Glance vs Glimpse
See (Verb): To perceive with eyes.
Example: I saw the ball hit the stump.
Look (Verb): To direct gaze.
Example: Look at the scoreboard.

Stare (Verb): To gaze fixedly.
Example: He stared at the umpire.
Peep (Verb): To look secretly.
Example: He peeped through the window.

Glare (Verb/Noun): Angry look / Bright light.
Example: He glared at the bowler.
Glow (Verb/Noun): Soft light.
Example: The trophy glowed in the light.

Glance (Verb/Noun): Quick look.
Example: He glanced at the clock.
Glimpse (Noun/Verb): Brief view.
Example: I caught a glimpse of the captain.

Light vs Burn
Light (Noun/Verb/Adjective): Illumination / Not heavy.
Example: The stadium lights were bright.
Burn (Verb/Noun): To be on fire.
Example: The sun burned his skin.

Catch vs Hold
Catch (Verb/Noun): To grab in air.
Example: He took a brilliant catch.
Hold (Verb/Noun): To grip.
Example: Hold the bat firmly.

Canvas vs Canvass
Canvas (Noun): Cloth.
Example: The banner was made of canvas.
Canvass (Verb): To campaign.
Example: They canvassed for fan support.

Refuse vs Deny vs Decline
Refuse (Verb): To reject.
Example: He refused to play.
Deny (Verb): To say not true.
Example: He denied cheating.
Decline (Verb): To refuse politely.
Example: He declined the interview.

Peddle vs Pedal
Peddle (Verb): To sell (illegally).
Example: He peddled fake tickets.
Pedal (Noun/Verb): Foot lever / To ride cycle.
Example: He pressed the pedal hard.

Ride vs Drive
Ride (Verb/Noun): To sit on and control (horse/bike).
Example: He rides a bike to the ground.
Drive (Verb/Noun): To operate (car).
Example: He drives the team bus.

Wither vs Weather vs Whether
Wither (Verb): To dry up.
Example: The grass withered in heat.
Weather (Noun/Verb): Climate / To survive.
Example: The match weathered the storm.
Whether (Conjunction): If.
Example: Whether we win or lose...

Sink vs Drown
Sink (Verb): To go down in water.
Example: The ball sank in the lake.
Drown (Verb): To die in water.
Example: He nearly drowned in the pool.

Cease vs Seize
Cease (Verb): To stop.
Example: Play ceased due to rain.
Seize (Verb): To grab.
Example: Police seized fake tickets.

Invent vs Discover
Invent (Verb): To create something new.
Example: He invented a new bat grip.
Discover (Verb): To find something existing.
Example: He discovered a talent in bowling.
